(b)  Effective July 1, 2005 impoundment fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  First offense, twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(2)  Second offense for the same animal, fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(3)  Third and subsequent offense for the same animal, one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17) 
Sec. 5-79. - Disposition of unclaimed animals. 
The animal control officer shall be authorized to dispose of any animal impounded under this article in as humane and painless a manner as possible, or to donate any animal to a public or nonprofit institution or agency, if such animal has remained unclaimed for the prescribed period of time or if it has been injured and is suffering or in a great pain and such animal does not display an identification tag and no determination of the owner can be made from a reasonable investigation. The disposal of any animal as provided in this section does not relieve the owner of any liability for any violation of this chapter. If the owner of any animal is known or ascertainable, but for a valid reason cannot be reached within the four (4) working day period, the animal control officer shall be authorized to hold the animal until such time as the owner can be reached. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17) 
Secs. 5-80—5-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESPONSIBLE DOG OWNERSHIP[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Dangerous dog control law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 

Sec. 5-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Altered means it shall be the duty of the owner of a dog or cat declared by an authority or court of competent jurisdiction to be a potentially dangerous, dangerous, dangerous or vicious animal, to have the animal surgically sterilized. Such sterilization must be performed by a licensed veterinarian within thirty (30) days of a final order of an authority or court of competent jurisdiction declaring the animal to be a potentially dangerous animal, dangerous animal, or vicious animal. 
Classified animal means any animal that has been classified as either dangerous or vicious animal pursuant to this article. Classifications are permanent until the death of the animal. 
Dangerous animal means any animal that: 
(1)  Causes a substantial puncture of a person's skin by teeth without causing serious injury; or 
(2)  Aggressively attacks in a manner that causes a person to reasonably believe that the animal posed an imminent threat of serious injury to such person or another person although no such injury occurs; or 
(3)  While off the owner's property kills a pet animal; provided, however, that this subparagraph shall not apply where the death of such pet animal is caused by a dog that is working or training as a hunting dog, herding dog, or predator control dog; where certain conditions apply, see section 5-102; or 
(4)  Has previously been found to be a potentially dangerous animal and has repeated the same behavior under potentially dangerous animal sections 5-1, 5-2, or 5-3. 
Fence means any structure of wire, wood, stone or other material, which is of sufficient height and strength to act as a barrier against passage of the animal it is intended to enclose. A fence shall be sufficient to prevent the animal from being able to jump, dig, or escape from confinement; and shall have slats installed for chain link if it is the only barrier to contain a dangerous animal. 
Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping, or having custody or care of control of an animal. In the case of an animal owned by a minor, the term "owner" includes the parents or person in loco parentis with custody of the minor. 
Pen means a pad-locked, fenced area within a perimeter fenced area that has secure sides that are buried two (2) feet into the ground or sunken in concrete and a secure top. 
Potentially dangerous animal means any animal that: 
(1)  Without provocation, endangers the safety of humans; or 
(2)  An animal that bites or attacks a person or pet animal without causing injury; or 
(3)  An animal that has been found " running at large more than one (1) time in a six (6) month period; or 
(4)  Which, because of temperament, conditioning, or training, has a known propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack, bite, or injure humans or other animals without provocation. 
Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping 
(1)  A potentially dangerous animal, while on the owner's property, securely and locked confined indoors or in a securely enclosed pad-locked fenced in area. Such enclosure shall be suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the animal from escaping. All sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the animal's escape from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the animal. 
(2)  A dangerous animal, while on the owner's property, securely confined indoors or inside an enclosed and locked pen constructed with a fence, or inside a fence with slats inserted, if said fence is the only barrier to maintain said dangerous animal and maintained and suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the animal from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top. If the animal is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the animal's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the animal. 
(3)  A vicious animal, while on the owner's property, securely confined and enclosed and locked pen, with fence, and shall be separate from the chain link fencing and it shall have slats, and such structure shall be suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the animal from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top and a secure bottom. The pen shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the animal's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the animal. 
Residential lot means the lot with a dwelling located thereon, exclusive of any vacant lots adjacent thereto under the same ownership. 
Serious injury means any physical injury that creates a substantial risk of death; results in death, broken or dislocated bones, lacerations requiring multiple sutures, or disfiguring avulsion; requires plastic surgery or admission to a hospital; or results in protracted impairment of health, including transmission of an infection or contagious disease, or impairment of the function of any bodily organ. 
Vicious animal means any animal that: 
(1)  Inflicts serious injury on a person or causes serious injury to a person resulting from reasonable attempts to escape from the animal's attack; or 
(2)  In the opinion of a judge, presents a threat of serious harm to other animals or humans; or 
(3)  Has previously attacked or bitten a human or injured a pet animal and has attacked or bitten a human or pet animal for second time; or 
(4)  Has been previously classified as a dangerous animal and has attacked or bitten a human or pet animal for second time. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17) 
Sec. 5-102. - Exemptions from article. 
No dog shall be classified as a potentially dangerous dog, dangerous dog or vicious dog for actions that occur while the dog is being used by a law enforcement or military officer to carry out the law enforcement or military officer's official duties. No dog shall be classified as a potentially dangerous dog, dangerous dog or vicious dog if the person injured by such dog was a person who, at the time, was committing a trespass, was abusing the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime; or training, hunting, herding exemption from dangerous dog restraint/leash requirement. In addition to the requirements otherwise specified by this Code section and O.C.G.A. § 4-8-29(a)(3), the person training the dog(s) must be the owner thereof, and must be in compliance with all Department of Natural Resources requirements including, without limitation: 
(1)  The trainer must hold a valid hunting license on his/her person; 
(2)  The training location must be with the consent of the property owner where he/she is hunting; 
(3)  The training, hunting, herding and/or predator control cannot take place off the property of the owner thereof, unless with the express written permission and acknowledgement of dangerousness of the dog granted by the owner of the land being used; and 
(4)  The training can only be done with a dog that will instantly respond to the verbal commands of the dog's owner, including without limitation a command to immediately heel and/or return to the owner. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17) 
Sec. 5-103. - Violation of article. 
(a)  Except as otherwise specified in this article, any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  (1)  It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dangerous or vicious animal to leave said animal unattended with minors. 
(2)  A person who violates subsection (1) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dangerous or vicious animal to leave said animal unattended with other pets. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17; Ord. No. 15-18, § 1, 5-21-18) 
Sec. 5-104. - Animal control board. 
(a)  The mayor and council hereby establish an animal control board to hold hearings as provided by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23. 
(b)  This board is created in conjunction with the cities of Warner Robins, Centerville, and Perry and with Houston County and shall be comprised of one (1) representative each from each government. 
(c)  No member of the animal control board may participate in a hearing on any matter in which such member previously participated in the classification of the animal at issue. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17) 
Sec. 5-105. - Investigation; notice to owner. 
(a)  Upon receiving a report of an animal believed to be subject to classification as a potentially dangerous animal within the animal control officer's jurisdiction, the animal control officer shall make such investigations as necessary to determine whether such animal is subject to classification as a potentially dangerous animal. 
(1)  The animal control officer shall mail a dated notice within seventy-two (72) hours. 
(2)  Notice shall include animal control officer's determination and shall state what qualifications/regulations the owner must be in accordance with. 
(3)  There shall be no appeal process under the "potentially dangerous" classification. 
(4)  If it is determined that the potentially dangerous animal shall be classified as a dangerous animal, the owner shall comply with the applicable requirements under state and local law. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17) 
Sec. 5-106. - Duties of owner; registration fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner to have or possess within the city a potentially dangerous animal, or an animal that has been classified as "dangerous" or "vicious" without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of state and local law. Certificates of registration shall be nontransferable and shall only be issued to a person eighteen (18) years of age or older. No more than one (1) certificate of registration shall be issued per domicile. 
(b)  Unless otherwise specified by this section, a certificate of registration for a potentially dangerous animal shall be issued if the animal control officer determines that the following requirements have been met: 
(1)  The owner has maintained a proper enclosure for a potentially dangerous animal; and 
(2)  A microchip containing an identification number and capable of being scanned has been injected under the skin between the shoulder blades of the animal; and owner must provide verifiable proof of registration to the animal control officer within five (5) business days; and shall be kept up to date; and 
(3)  The animal has been altered and owner must provide verifiable proof to the animal control officer within thirty (30) days from date of classification; and 
(4)  The animal is current on rabies inoculations and provides proof and attaches rabies tag to animal's collar at all times; and 
(5)  The owner nor any occupant of such residence, where said owner is residing, is already in possession of a potentially dangerous or classified animal; and no certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of two (2) or more violations of this article; and no person shall be the owner of more than one (1) potentially dangerous, or classified animal; and 
(6)  Owner or lessor of said property, where owner of animal resides, must give written consent granting approval and knowledge that the resident owns a potentially dangerous animal; and 
(7)  Notify animal control officer upon the animal being sold, transferred ownership, died or attacked a human or pet animal with twenty-four (24) hours or owner has moved. 
(c)  Unless otherwise specified by this section, a certificate of registration for a dangerous animal shall be issued if the animal control officer determines that the following requirements have been met: 
(1)  The owner had maintained a proper enclosure designed for a dangerous animal; and 
(2)  Clearly visible warning signs have been posted at or on all entrances to the pen and posted at the entrance to the premises where the animal resides; and 
(3)  A microchip containing an identification number and capable of being scanned has been injected under the skin between the shoulder blades of the animal; and owner must provide verifiable proof of registration to the animal control officer within five (5) business days; and shall be kept up to date; and 
(4)  The animal has been altered and owner must provide verifiable proof to the animal control officer within thirty (30) days from classification or date of hearing; and 
(5)  The animal is current on rabies inoculations and provides proof and attaches rabies tag to animal's collar at all times; and 
(6)  The owner nor any occupant of such residence, where said owner is residing, is already in possession of a potentially dangerous or classified animal, or any person who has been convicted of two (2) or more violations of this section ; and no person shall be the owner of more than one (1) potentially dangerous, or classified animal; and 
(7)  The owner shall maintain and can provide proof of general or specific liability insurance in the amount of at least fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in this state insuring the owner of the dangerous animal against liability for any bodily injury or property damage caused by the animal; and 
(8)  No owner can keep/house a classified animal within two hundred (200) yards of any structure or manmade improvement that is an aquatic center, church, convenience store, daycare, grocery store, hospital, humane society, library, nursing home, park, playground, restaurant, school, skilled nursing unit, or walking trail, due in part to these areas being frequented by children and senior citizens, and in some cases having food present; and 
(9)  Owner or lessor of said property, where owner of animal resides, must give written consent granting approval and knowledge that resident owns a potentially dangerous, dangerous, or vicious animal; and 
(10)  Owner of a dangerous animal shall be charged an annual registration fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(d)  Unless otherwise specified by this section, a certificate of registration for a vicious animal shall be issued if the animal control officer determines that the following requirements have been met: 
(1)  The owner has maintained an enclosure designed to securely confine the animal on the owner's property in a securely pad-locked and enclosed pen; and 
(2)  Clearly visible warning signs have been posted at or on all entrances to the pen and posted at the entrance to the premises where the animal resides; and 
(3)  A microchip containing an identification number and capable of being scanned has been injected under the skin between the shoulder blades of the animal; and owner must provide verifiable proof of registration to the animal control officer within five (5) business days; and shall be kept up to date; and 
(4)  The animal has been altered and owner must provide verifiable proof to the animal control officer within thirty (30) days of classification or date of hearing; and 
(5)  The animal is current on rabies inoculations and provides proof and attaches rabies tag to animal's collar at all times; and 
(6)  The owner nor any occupant of such residence, where said owner is residing, is already in possession of a potentially dangerous or classified animal, or any person who has been convicted of two (2) or more violations of this section; and no person shall be the owner of more than one (1) potentially dangerous, dangerous or vicious animal; and 
(7)  Owner or lessor of said property, where owner of animal resides, must give written consent granting approval and knowledge that resident owns a vicious animal; and 
(8)  The owner shall maintain and can provide proof of general or specific liability insurance in the amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in this state insuring the owner of the vicious animal against liability for any bodily injury or property damage caused by the animal; and 
(9)  No owner can keep/house a classified animal within two hundred (200) yards of any structure or manmade improvement that is an aquatic center, church, convenience store, daycare, grocery store, hospital, humane society, library, nursing home, park, playground, restaurant, school, skilled nursing unit, or walking trail, due in part to these areas being frequented by children and senior citizens, and in some cases having food present; and 
(10)  Owner of a vicious animal shall be charged an annual registration fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(e)  No certificate shall be issued to the owner of more than one (1) potentially dangerous, dangerous, or vicious animal, nor to any occupant of such residence where said owner is residing, already possessing a potentially dangerous, dangerous, or vicious animal, nor to any person who has been convicted of two (2) or more violations of this section. 
(f)  No person shall be the owner of more than one (1) potentially dangerous, dangerous, or vicious animal. 
(g)  No certificate of registration for a vicious animal shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of: 
(1)  A serious violent felony as defined in O.C.G.A. § 17-10-6.1; 
(2)  The felony of dog fighting as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37, or the felony of aggravated cruelty to animals as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; or 
(3)  A felony involving trafficking in cocaine, illegal drugs, marijuana, methamphetamine, or ecstasy as provided for in O.C.G.A. §§ 16-13-31 and 16-13-31.1 from the time of conviction until two (2) years after completion of his or her sentence, nor to any person residing with such person. 
(h)  Certificates of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of renewal of a certificate of registration for a potentially dangerous, dangerous, or vicious animal, an animal control officer shall verify that the owner is continuing to comply with provisions of this article. Failure to renew a certificate of registration within ten (10) days of the renewal date or initial classification date shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(i)  The owner of a classified animal shall notify the animal control officer within twenty-four (24) hours if the animal is on the loose or has attacked a human or attacked a pet animal and shall notify the animal control officer within twenty-four (24) hours if the animal has died or has been euthanized. 
(j)  A vicious animal shall not be transferred, sold, or donated to any other person unless it is relinquished to a governmental facility or veterinarian to be euthanized. 
(k)  The owner of a potentially dangerous animal or classified animal who moves from one (1) jurisdiction to another within the State of Georgia shall register the potentially dangerous or classified animal in the new jurisdiction within ten (10) days of becoming a resident and notify the animal control officer of the jurisdiction from which he or she moved. The owner of a similarly classified animal who moves into this state shall register the animal as required in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27 within thirty (30) days of becoming a resident. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17) 
Sec. 5-107. - Confinement. 
It shall be unlawful for an owner of a: 
(1)  Potentially dangerous animal to allow that animal outside of a proper enclosure unless that animals is on a leash less than four (4) feet not including flexi-leashes; and 
(2)  Dangerous or vicious animal to allow that animal outside of a proper enclosure unless that animal is: 
a.  On a leash less than four (4) feet not including flexi-leashes; and 
b.  Wearing a secure wire basket muzzle at all times. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17) 
Sec. 5-108. - Confiscation of dogs. 
(a)  A potentially dangerous animal, dangerous animal or vicious animal shall be immediately confiscated by any animal control officer or by a law enforcement officer in the case of any violation of this article. A refusal to surrender an animal subject to confiscation shall be a violation of this article. 
(b)  The owner of any animal that has been confiscated pursuant to this article may recover such animal upon payment of all reasonable confiscation and housing costs and proof of compliance with the provisions of this article, unless such confiscation is deemed to be in error by the animal control officer, an authority defined in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23, or the municipal court. All fines and all charges for services performed by a law enforcement or animal control officer shall be paid prior to owner recovery of the animal. Criminal prosecution shall not be stayed due to owner recovery or euthanasia of the animal. 
(c)  In the event the owner has not complied with the provisions of this article within fourteen (14) days of the date the dog was confiscated, such animal shall be released to an animal shelter, as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 4-14-2, or euthanized in an expeditious and humane manner. The owner may be required to pay the costs of housing and euthanasia. 
(Ord. No. 32-17, § 1(Exh.), 6-19-17)

Sec. 6-1. - Numbering of structures. 
(a)  All owners of real property upon which a structure has been erected, whether used for residential, commercial or industrial purposes, shall be required to place building numbers on the structure visible from the roadway. Arabic numerals shall be placed on both sides of a mailbox which is freestanding by the road right-of-way or immediately above or beside the front door of the structure. When a structure does not have such type mailbox, then Arabic numerals shall be required on the side of the building or on a sign in the yard, visible from the roadway. When placed on a mailbox, numerals a minimum of three (3) inches in height shall be used; four-inch numerals shall be required for any other placement. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a), all owners of real property used as multifamily apartment buildings shall be required to place upon the structure, visible from the roadway, the building letter or number, and, in addition, the number of each unit contained therein shall be placed on or near the front door of such unit. Arabic numerals a minimum of four (4) inches in height shall be used. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1012) 
Sec. 6-2. - Exemption from self-inspection of certain water and sewer lines. 
Pursuant to the authority contained in Section 3 of Act 1046 Georgia Laws, subsection (d) of Code Section 8-2-26 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to self-inspection of water and sewer projects by master plumbers or utility contractors, shall not be applicable within the City of Warner Robins. 
(Ord. No. 46-96, § 1, 6-17-96) 
Secs. 6-3—6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-26. - Adoption. 
A certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the 2012 International Building Code, is hereby adopted as the building code of the city, which building code regulates the construction, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of buildings and structures, including permits and penalties within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1001; Ord. No. 43-89, § 1, 8-21-89; Ord. No. 45-91, § 1, 8-19-91; Ord. No. 52-93, § 1, 10-4-93; Ord. No. 62-04, 12-20-04; Memo. of 7-12-11; Ord. No. 07-14, § 1, 3-17-14) 
Charter reference— Adoption of technical codes by reference, § 2-404. 
State Law reference— Buildings and housing, § 8-2-20 et seq. 
Sec. 6-27. - Additions, insertions, deletions and changes. 
Each townhouse shall be considered a separate building and shall be separated from adjoining townhouses by the use of separate exterior walls meeting the requirements of Table 600 for zero clearance from property lines as required for the type of construction, and shall have roof sheathing of noncombustible material, or fire retardant treated wood, or one (1) layer of five-eighths inch (16 mm) type X gypsum board attached to the underside of roof decking, for not less than four (4) feet (1219 mm) width on each side of the exterior dividing wall; or by a party wall, or one layer of five-eighths inch (16 mm) type X gypsum board attached to the underside of the ceiling joist throughout the entire townhouse. 
(Ord. No. 46-91, § 2, 8-19-91) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 45-91, § 8, adopted 8-19-91, repealed in its entirety § 6-27, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1002, regarding additions, insertions, deletions and changes to the building code. Ordinance No. 46-91, § 2, adopted 8-19-91, established a local amendment to the Standard Building Code. Such section, not being specifically amendatory, has been classified herein as § 6-27, regarding additions, insertions, deletions and changes to the building code at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 6-28. - Requirements not covered by code. 
Any requirements necessary for the strength or stability of an existing or proposed building or structure, or for the safety of the occupants thereof, not specifically covered by the code under this article, shall be determined by the building official subject to appeal to the mayor and council. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1003) 
Sec. 6-29. - Alternate materials and alternate methods of construction. 
The provisions of this article are not intended to prevent the use of any material or method of construction not specifically prescribed by this article, provided the alternate has been approved and its use authorized by the building official. The building official shall approve any alternate, provided he finds that the proposed design is satisfactory and complies with the provisions of the Southern Standard Building Code, and that the material, method or work offered is, for the purpose intended, at least the equivalent of that prescribed in the building code in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire-resistance, durability and safety. The building official shall require that sufficient evidence or proof be submitted to substantiate any claims that may be made regarding its use. If, in the opinion of the building official, the evidence and proof are not sufficient to justify approval, the applicant may refer the entire matter to the mayor and council as specified in section 6-32. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1004) 
Sec. 6-30. - Liability. 
Any suit brought against any officer or employee because of an act performed by him in the enforcement of any provision of this article shall be defended by the city attorney until the final termination of the proceedings. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1005) 
Sec. 6-31. - Reports. 
The building official shall annually submit a report to the mayor and council covering the work of the department during the preceding year. He shall incorporate in the report a summary of the decisions of the mayor and council on appeal from his decision during the year. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1006) 
Sec. 6-32. - Appeals. 
(a)  Whenever the building official shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of construction proposed to be followed, or materials to be used in the erection or alteration of a building or structure, or when it is claimed that the provisions of this code do not apply, or that an equally good or more desirable form of construction can be employed in any specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of this article or any of the regulations hereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the owner of the building or structure, or his duly authorized agent, may appeal from the decision of the building official to the mayor and council. Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed within ninety (90) days after the decision is rendered by the building official. 
(b)  In case of a building or structure which, in the opinion of the building official, is unsafe, or dangerous, the building official may, in his order, limit the time for this appeal to a shorter period. Appeals hereunder shall be on forms provided by the building official. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1007) 
Sec. 6-33. - Fire limits designated. 
All of the territory lying within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated as the fire limits of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1008) 
Sec. 6-34. - Schedule of permit fees. 
(a)  On all buildings, structures or alterations requiring a building permit, as set forth in section 105 of the building code, the fee shall be paid as required at the time of filing application, in accordance with the following schedule: 

 
(b)  Notwithstanding the schedule outlined above, a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be payable for a permit allowing the erection, construction or placement of a satellite receiving dish antenna. 
(c)  A fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be payable for a permit for the rehabilitation of an existing residential structure through the city's community development department. 
(d)  There shall be a reinspection fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for all additional inspections required in excess of two (2) per required inspection. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1009; Ord. No. 37-90, §§ 2, 4, 6-18-90; Ord. No. 12-97, § 1, 1-21-97; Ord. No. 76-02, § 1, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 27-04, §§ 1, 9, 6-21-04; Ord. No. 24-11, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Sec. 6-35. - Tap-in, sewer connection and utility fees, when payable. 
All tap-in fees, sewer connection fees and other utility fees that are presently charged by the city are to be paid to the city clerk at the time the building permit is issued. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1011) 
Sec. 6-36. - Building restricted within one-hundred-year floodplain. 
All construction or building development shall comply with the provisions and regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program floodplain management criteria promulgated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). Such rules, regulations and subsequent revisions shall be incorporated herein by reference as part of the ordinances of the city. Such rules and regulations shall be found within the zoning regulations of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1010) 
Cross reference— Zoning, app. C. 
Sec. 6-37. - Building permit fee chart. 

 
(Ord. No. 24-11, 7-18-11) 
Secs. 6-38—6-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SITE PLANS FOR COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS 

Sec. 6-51. - Site plan to accompany commercial building permit application. 
Applications for all commercial building permits shall be accompanied by a site plan. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1015) 
Sec. 6-52. - Site plan—Information required. 
The site plan shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  Generally. 
a.  Name, address, telephone number of property owner; 
b.  Name, address, telephone number of person or firm preparing site plan; 
c.  North arrow and scale; 
d.  Distance to nearest land lot line or right-of-way intersection; 
e.  Date; 
f.  Title or project description. 
(2)  Existing conditions. 
a.  Existing contours or spot elevations; 
b.  Location of existing structures, curbing, drives, etc.; 
c.  Location of existing utilities (sanitary sewer, water, gas) with elevation data; 
d.  Location of existing drainage facilities (ditches, culverts, inlets) with elevation data. 
(3)  Proposed conditions. 
a.  Proposed contours or spot elevations; 
b.  Location of proposed structures, curbing, drives, etc.; 
c.  Details of typical driveway entrance; 
d.  Detail of pavement patch, if applicable; 
e.  Parking layout; 
f.  Drainage layout, with elevations; 
g.  Utility layout, with elevations; 
h.  Floodway limits (if applicable). 
(Code 1977, § 9-1016) 
Sec. 6-53. - Same—Review by city engineering department. 
Such site plans shall be referred to the city engineering department for review immediately upon receipt. The city engineer shall act as promptly as possible, but in not more than five (5) days, barring extenuating circumstances. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1017; Ord. No. 03-09, 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 6-54. - Same—Additional information required by city engineering department. 
If the city engineering department is unable to determine compliance with applicable laws or regulations from the original site plan, he may require additional plans and/or information and shall have five (5) days from the receipt of such plans and/or information in which to act. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1018; Ord. No. 03-09, 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 6-55. - Same—Approval prerequisite to issuance of building permit. 
No permit for building construction shall be issued for a commercial lot until a site plan is approved by the city engineering department and the building official. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1019; Ord. No. 03-09, 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 6-56. - Same—Procedure on denial of permit. 
If the decision is to deny the permit, the building official shall return the drawings to the applicant with his refusal to issue such permit. Such refusal shall, when requested, be in writing and shall contain the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1020) 
Sec. 6-57. - Same—Right of appeal. 
The applicant under this division shall have the right to appeal as set forth in section 6-32. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1020.1) 
Secs. 6-58—6-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-76. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Journeyman electrician means any person actually doing the work of electrical installation, construction and repair. No license shall be required of a journeyman electrician but except as hereinafter provided he shall at all times be working under the supervision of a master electrician as hereinafter set out. 
Master electrician means any person who shall have passed the examination hereinafter set out, and who shall have been issued a certificate by the board of examiners, all as hereinafter set out. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1023) 
Sec. 6-77. - Liability for damage unimpaired by article. 
(a)  Nothing herein contained shall be construed to relieve any firm or company from liability in case of accident, to life, or damage to property, in the operation of its plant or plants. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to relieve any person from liability, or moral responsibility for damage or injury to life or property. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1027) 
Sec. 6-78. - Electrical inspector—Right of entry for inspection purposes. 
The electrical inspector shall have the right in the discharge of his duties to enter any building under construction or completed, or any manhole or subway, or climb any pole, for the purpose of examining and testing all electrical wires, construction or appliances therein or thereon contained and for that purpose he shall be given prompt access to all buildings, public or private, and to all manholes, subways or poles. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1062) 
Sec. 6-79. - Same—Authority to condemn unsafe wiring, etc. 
The electrical inspector shall have authority to condemn any electrical wiring, equipment or appliance which, in his opinion, is unsafe to life or property and after three (3) days' notice shall order the current discontinued from this electrical wiring equipment or appliance. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1063) 
Sec. 6-80. - Authority of electrical inspector—To cut out lights or current for violation of article. 
If the electrical inspector finds a violation of any section of this article, he shall have the authority after due notice to cut out lights or current in any locality concerned and to enforce discontinuance thereof until requirements are met. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1031) 
Sec. 6-81. - Same—To condemn wiring, etc. 
The electrical inspector shall have authority to condemn any electrical wiring, equipment and appliance which he finds is unsafe to life or property, and after three (3) days' notice shall order the current discontinued for that electrical wiring, equipment and appliance. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1032) 
Sec. 6-82. - Failure to correct defective work; effect. 
Any person that shall fail to correct any defects in his work within five (5) days after having been duly notified of defects by the electrical inspector shall not receive any further permit until the defect or defects have been corrected. Immediately after the correction of the defect or defects, the electrical inspector shall be notified of these corrections. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1033) 
Sec. 6-83. - Revocation of license or permit; notice; appeal. 
After five (5) days' notice any license or permit granted to any electrician may be revoked by the board of examiners should this electrician be found guilty of violation of this article or any ordinance governing electrical work. Any person found guilty under this section shall have the right to appeal the decision to the municipal court and there have a trial on the evidence to determine whether the decision was justified. This appeal shall be made in writing within five (5) days after the decision or judgment appealed from. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1035) 
Sec. 6-84. - License required; term, transferability. 
(a)  Every person desiring to engage in the business of electrical construction and of the installation of wiring and apparatus for electric light, heat or power in the city shall before doing so, obtain a business license from the city clerk therefor. The license shall be issued by the city clerk after the presentation of certificate from the board of electrical examiners or presentation of a valid state-wide license. 
(b)  License granted under this article shall be for one (1) year, shall not be transferrable and the full fee shall be charged for any year or fraction thereof, and it shall be unlawful to do any electrical work in the city without license. 
(Code 1977, §§ 9-1024, 9-1025) 
Sec. 6-85. - Master electrician required to do or supervise work. 
It shall be unlawful to do any work of electrical installation, construction, or repair unless done by or under the personal supervision of a master electrician, as defined in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1026) 
Sec. 6-86. - Fire damage. 
(a)  Approval of electrical department prerequisite to resumption of services. Electrical services shall not be resumed on or in the premises of any building or structure damaged by fire without the approval of the electrical inspector. Approval will be given if the building or structure complies with all laws and ordinances. 
(b)  Ruling from electrical inspector required for replacement of wiring. Before beginning work of any electrical installation damaged by fire, a ruling shall be obtained from the electrical inspector, as to what part of the wiring must be replaced. The inspector shall order any wiring that is unsafe or not in compliance with all laws and ordinances to be removed. All old wiring not in use shall be removed. 
(c)  Inspector; authority to cut wire or service. In the event of fire in any building or structure, the electrical inspector shall have full power and authority to cut and remove any electrical wire or service to any building. 
(Code 1977, §§ 9-1065—9-1067) 
Secs. 6-87—6-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 6-101. - Permit required; application; details. 
(a)  No person shall commence any kind of electrical installation, alteration or repairs until a permit has been issued by the electrical inspector. 
(b)  Applicant for a permit shall furnish the inspector a statement of the electrical installation, with a written application or statement under oath to be administered by the inspector or his assistant showing the locality and giving all installation alterations or repairs to be done and the approximate cost including labor and materials to do the work for which the permit is being requested. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1051) 
Sec. 6-102. - Exceptions to permit requirements. 
This article shall not cover minor electrical repairs involving no new work, alteration or change that may be necessary or incident to the maintenance only in good condition of an established plant, installation or system of wiring, but this qualification does not extend to installation of new circuits or the extension of any circuits already installed, or the installation of any apparatus, devices or materials for which a permit is required under this article. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1053) 
Sec. 6-103. - Application to be filed with electrical department; forms. 
Before beginning any work of electrical installation an application for permit shall be made to the electrical inspector on forms furnished for that purpose which application shall contain an accurate and detailed account of the electrical work contemplated as provided for in all forms furnished. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1052) 
Sec. 6-104. - Information required for issuance of permit; fees; issuance of permit. 
(a)  Any person proposing to do wiring work and installation of electrical apparatus or fixtures for use in connection with electricity shall before undertaking the work or making the installations file with the city electrical inspector a statement in writing which shall give the proposed location by street and number and the name of the person for whom the work is to be done and also shall set out in detail the amount of wiring, electrical work, electrical apparatus, or other electrical devices or fixtures for use in connection with the statements prepared in the office of the city electrical inspector; with this information shall be included the amount of fees set out in this article. 
(b)  When the fees have been paid, the building inspection office or the electrical inspector shall approve the application, if it meets all necessary requirements, and issue a permit therefor. 
(c)  The following fees shall be charged and collected by the city clerk at the time the permits are issued: 
(1)  Commercial: 
One (1) percent of total electrical contract price up to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
One-half (.005) percent of amount over ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(2)  New residence: 
Single-family dwellings—Fifty dollars ($50.00) per living unit. 
Multi-family dwellings (Apartment building, condo, duplexes, etc.)—Fifty dollars ($50.00) per living unit. 
(3)  Miscellaneous: 

 
(4)  Rehab projects (if needed): Forty dollars ($40.00). 
(5)  Low voltage: 
One (1) percent of total electrical contract price up to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
One-half (.005) percent of amount over ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(Code 1977, § 9-1054; Ord. No. 37-90, § 3, 6-18-90; Ord. No. 56-93, § 1, 10-18-93; Ord. No. 12-97, § 1, 1-21-97; Ord. No. 76-02, §§ 2—4, 7, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 27-04, §§ 2—4, 7, 6-21-04; Ord. No. 50-05, 10-17-05; Ord. No. 54-05, § 1, 11-7-05; Ord. No. 24-11, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Sec. 6-105. - Inspector authorized to require general plan. 
If requested by the electrical inspector, the applicant shall file a general plan of construction and detailed description of apparatus, device, appliances or fixtures to be used in the work. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1055) 
Sec. 6-106. - Proceedings to collect unpaid fees, etc. 
If any person shall do any work covered by this article without filing a statement as herein provided and paying the fees herein ordained the electrical inspector shall make out a bill therefor and transmit it to the city clerk, who shall issue a fi. fa. in the name of the city against such a person in the usual form of executions issued by the city and turn it over to the marshal who shall proceed to levy and collect it in the same manner as he does any other for collection, such as levy, advertisement and sale, etc. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1056) 
Sec. 6-107. - New applications to be rejected until all unpaid fees are paid. 
If any person shall violate this article, and shall undertake any electrical work requiring permit and payment of fees as herein provided, and shall thereafter make applications to the office of the electrical inspector for permit to do other and different and independent electrical work covered by this article, the electrical inspector shall not consider the application and shall not grant it unless the fees for the previous work, which were not paid, shall have been first paid. In this event, if fees for this previous work are then paid, then the electrical inspector shall consider the new application. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1057) 
Sec. 6-108. - New application required for additional work. 
If after obtaining permit for electrical work, it is found necessary to change or increase the load of electric current, an application for permit shall be filed covering the additional work. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1058) 
Sec. 6-109. - Alterations in wiring or rated load prohibited. 
No alterations shall be made in the wiring of any building or structure for light, heat or power or increase in the rated load as fixed by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1059) 
Sec. 6-110. - Wiring; covering or concealing; inspection. 
It shall be unlawful for any persons, their agents or employees to cover or conceal any electrical wiring in the city except upon the following conditions: 
Whenever it is desired to conceal any electrical wiring, the electrical inspector shall be notified and it shall be his duty to inspect the wiring and if approved by him as being in conformity with this article, the rules prescribed hereunder, the statutes of the state and the approved methods of construction for safety to life and property, he shall issue a certificate to be known as a certificate of inspection which shall authorize the concealing of the wiring. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1064) 
Sec. 6-111. - Failure to pay permit fees; effect. 
As a cumulative remedy, if any person shall violate this article, and shall undertake any electrical work requiring permit and payment of fees, as herein provided and shall thereafter make application to the office of the city clerk for permit to do other and different and independent electrical work, covered by this article, the electrical inspector shall not grant it unless the fees for the previous work are then paid; then the electrical inspector shall consider the new application for other and different work as herein provided. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1034) 
Sec. 6-112. - Reinspection fee. 
There shall be reinspection fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for all additional inspections required in excess of two (2) per required inspection. 
(Ord. No. 76-02, § 9, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 24-11, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Secs. 6-113—6-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS 

Sec. 6-131. - Adoption of electrical code. 
A certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the National Electrical Code, 2014 edition, which code is the standard for electrical wiring and apparatus of the National Fire Protection Association, is hereby adopted as the electrical code of the city, and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of this electrical code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part of this article as if set forth verbatim herein. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1021; Ord. No. 39-90, § 1, 7-2-90; Ord. No. 52-93, § 1, 10-4-93; Ord. No. 62-04, 12-20-04; Memo. of 7-12-11; Ord. No. 07-14, § 1, 3-17-14; Ord. No. 03-15, § 1, 2-17-15) 
Editor's note— The user's attention is directed to the editor's note at the title of this chapter wherein the city's intention of enforcing the latest edition of the National Electric Code is set forth. 
Charter reference— Adoption of technical codes by reference, § 2-404. 
State Law reference— Buildings and housing, § 8-2-20 et seq. 
Secs. 6-132, 6-133. - Reserved.

Sec. 6-134. - Outside disconnections on buildings. 
All buildings and structures in the city, whether commercial, residential or otherwise, built subsequent to the adoption of this section, shall provide a device by which electrical service to said building is accessible for disconnection, notwithstanding the fact that the electrical disconnect may be locked or secured in safe manner. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1020.2; Ord. No. 45-91, § 8, 8-19-91; Ord. No. 46-91, § 1, 8-19-91) 
Sec. 6-135. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 45-91, § 8, adopted 8-19-91, repealed in its entirety § 6-135, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1068, regarding fuse gaps in ungrounded conductor. This section has been reserved at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 6-136. - Coverage. 
Services under this division include grounding of, disconnect and temporary. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1081) 
Sec. 6-137. - Conduit for service entrance wires. 
Service entrance wires in all buildings shall be run in two (2) inch minimum rigid conduit from meter base to a weatherhead for attachment of utility company's wires. This conduit shall extend a minimum of two (2) feet and a maximum of four (4) feet above the roof line at the point where the conduit passes through or by the roof. Conduit shall be securely strapped to the building, and in buildings with an overhang, shall pass through the overhang and be properly flashed, so as to be rain tight. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1082; Ord. No. 46-91, § 1, 8-19-91) 
Secs. 6-138—6-144. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 45-91, § 8, adopted 8-19-91, repealed the following sections in their entirety: § 6-138, derived from Code 9177, § 9-1083, regarding service conductors; § 6-139, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1084, regarding separately metered installations; § 6-140, derived from Code 1977, regarding meter installations; § 6-141, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1086, regarding service switches; § 6-142, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1087, regarding open wiring on insulators or racks; § 6-143, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1088, regarding concentric cable or entrance cable; and § 6-144, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1089, regarding circuits on three-phase, four-wire S/N Wye distribution panels; on single-phase three-wire S.N. distribution panels. These sections have been reserved at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 6-145. - Residential use service entrance wires. 
All service entrance wires for residential use from meter base to point of entry into building shall be installed in water tight E.M.T. tubing or rigid conduit. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1090; Ord. No. 46-91, § 1, 8-19-91) 
Secs. 6-146, 6-147. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 45-91, § 8, adopted 8-19-91, repealed the following sections in their entirety: § 6-146, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1091, regarding securing of service mast and § 6-147, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1092, regarding main service switch required. These sections have been reserved at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 6-148. - Temporary or trailer services. 
All temporary or trailer services shall be made up to weather tight main switch and receptacles. In the case of trailer services the entrance wires shall be run in conduit from the meter base up the pole to a point to provide sufficient clearance for the service drop. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1093; Ord. No. 46-91, § 1, 8-19-91) 
Secs. 6-149—6-156. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 45-91, § 8, adopted 8-19-91, repealed the following sections in their entirety: § 6-149, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1094, regarding grounding; § 6-150, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1102, regarding wire size for lighting or receptacle circuits; § 6-151, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1103, regarding identification of circuits; § 6-152, derived from Code of 1977, § 9-1104, regarding panel identification; § 6-153, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1105, regarding air conditioning compressors; § 6-154, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1106, regarding mixing of aluminum and copper conductors; § 6-155, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1107, regarding convenience outlets in buildings; and § 6-156, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1111, regarding regulations for manufacture and installation of electrical signs. These sections have been reserved at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 6-157. - Outline lighting and nonportable signs; switches. 
Each outline lighting installation and each sign of other than the portable type shall be controlled by an externally operable switch which will open all ungrounded conductors. This switch shall be within sight of the signs or outline which it controls, or may be located elsewhere if capable of being locked in the open position. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1112) 
Secs. 6-158, 6-159. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 45-91, § 8, adopted 8-19-91, repealed in the following sections in their entirety: §6-158, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1113, regarding portable type sign, regulations; and § 6-159, derived from Code 1977, § 9-1114, regarding show windows and outline lighting, regulations. These sections have been reserved at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 6-160—6-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GAS 

Sec. 6-176. - Adoption of gas code. 
A certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the 2012 International Fuel Gas Code, which code regulates the installation, alteration and maintenance of all piping extending from the point of delivery of gas for use as a fuel and designed to convey or carry it to gas appliances; regulates the installation and maintenance of appliances designed to utilize gas as a fuel; provides for the inspection of piping and certain appliances and the collection of inspection fees therefor; provides for the licensing of persons engaging in the business of installing, repairing or maintaining piping or certain appliances; and provides penalties for the violation thereof, is hereby adopted as the gas code of the city, and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of this gas code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part of this article as if fully set forth verbatim herein. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1131; Ord. No. 43-89, § 2, 8-21-89; Ord. No. 45-91, § 2, 8-19-91; Ord. No. 52-93, § 1, 10-4-93; Ord. No. 62-04, 12-20-04; Memo. of 7-12-11; Ord. No. 07-14, § 1, 3-17-14) 
Editor's note— The user's attention is directed to the editor's note at the title of this chapter wherein the city's intention of enforcing the latest edition of the International Fuel Gas Code is set forth. 
Charter reference— Adoption of technical codes by reference, § 2-404. 
Sec. 6-177. - Additions, insertions, deletions and changes. 
(a)  In the Standard Gas Code, the words "gas inspector" shall mean the building inspection department. 
(b)  Section 113 of the Standard Gas Code is deleted, and the following is substituted therefor: Inspection fees shall be in accordance with the fees on file in the office of the building official. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1132) 
Secs. 6-178—6-190. - Reserved.

A certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the 2012 International Plumbing Code, adopted by the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc., is hereby adopted as the plumbing code of the city; all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of this Standard Plumbing Code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a pert of this article, as though fully set out at length herein, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes as are prescribed in section 6-212 of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1151; Ord. No. 43-89, § 3, 8-21-89; Ord. No. 45-91, § 4, 8-19-91; Ord. No. 52-93, § 1, 10-4-93; Ord. No. 62-04, 12-20-04; Memo. of 7-12-11; Ord. No. 07-14, § 1, 3-17-14)

Sec. 6-212. - Additions, insertions, deletions and changes. 
(a)  Section 102 of the Standard Plumbing Code is deleted and wherever the words "plumbing official" are used in the code they shall mean building inspection department. 
(b)  The words "administrative authority" and the words "local governing body" as used in this code shall mean the mayor and council. 
(c)  The words "department of law" as used in the code shall mean the city attorney. 
(d)  The words "plumbing inspection department" shall mean the building inspection department. 
(e)  Plastic pipe is hereby approved for water mains and service lines. 
(f)  Backwater connection valves shall be required on all residential building structures constructed within the city and connected to the city's sanitary sewer system. These shall contain forty-five (45) degree long sweeps with clean-out valves on either side of the backwater valve. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1152; Ord. No. 35-96, § 1, 5-20-96) 
Sec. 6-213. - Inspection fees. 
Inspection fees shall be charged for the installation and/or removal and relocation of fixtures, according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Commercial: Five dollars ($5.00) per fixture for commercial projects (including floor drains). 
(2)  Residential: 
Five dollars ($5.00) per fixture for an addition (not to exceed twenty dollars ($20.00)). 
Fifty dollars ($50.00) per living unit (new single-family dwellings). 
Fifty dollars ($50.00) per living unit (multi-family dwellings). 
(3)  Rehab projects: Four dollars ($4.00) per fixture. 
(4)  Additions: Five dollars ($5.00) per fixture (not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00)). 
(5)  Heating and air conditioning: 
Commercial and industrial: 
a.  One (1) to fifteen (15) tons: Nine dollars and seventy-five cents ($9.75) per ton (15 × $9.75 = $146.25). 
b.  Sixteen (16) tons or more: Five dollars and twenty cents ($5.20) per ton (16 × $4.00 = $83.20). 
New single-family dwellings: Fifty dollars ($50.00). 
Add to existing home: Thirty dollars ($30.00). 
Change out old system: No charge. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1153; Ord. No. 37-90, § 1, 6-18-90; Ord. No. 37-92, § 1, 8-3-92; Ord. No. 56-93, § 2, 10-18-93; Ord. No. 12-97, § 1, 1-21-97; Ord. No. 54-01, 8-20-01; Ord. No. 76-02, §§ 5, 6, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 27-04, §§ 5, 6, 6-21-04; Ord. No. 24-11, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Sec. 6-214. - Pipe required to be used. 
All outside building sewer lines within the city shall be required to use Schedule 40 ASTM D2 665 plastic pipe and fittings or equivalent after June 18, 1990. 
(Ord. No. 37-90, § 5, 6-18-90; Ord. No. 46-91, § 1, 8-19-91) 
Secs. 6-215—6-230. - Reserved.
