After a contract shall have been let or an improvement shall have been made by the city in the event the mayor and council elects to have the work done by the city, as the case may be, and the cost for this improvement, which shall include all other expenses incurred by the city incident to the improvement in addition to the contract price for the work and materials or in addition to the cost of all materials, labor, machinery, equipment and services used in the making of this improvement in the event the work is done by the city shall have been ascertained, the mayor and council shall apportion the cost and expense to the several tracts of land abutting on the improvements and assess one-third of the total cost thereof against the real estate abutting on each side of the street upon which the improvement takes place, so that the abutting real property shall bear two-thirds of the entire cost and the city the additional one-third of the total cost. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1027) 
Sec. 22-8. - Objections to apportionment. 
(a)  Hearing; notice. When an apportionment of cost shall have been made, the mayor and council shall appoint a time for the holding of a session, or shall designate a regular meeting for the hearing of any complaints or objections that may be made concerning the apportionment and assessment by any person interested, and notice of this session for the hearing shall be published by the city clerk once in the official organ of the city. The notice shall provide for an inspection of this return by any property owner or other party interested in the return. 
(b)  Time for hearing. The time fixed for hearing shall not be less than five (5) nor more than ten (10) days from the date of the publication. 
(c)  Power, duty of mayor and council. The mayor and council shall have power, and it shall be its duty, to review and correct the apportionment and assessment, to hear objections thereto and to confirm them either as made or as corrected. The mayor and council shall by ordinance fix the assessments in accordance with the apportionment as so confirmed, against the several tracts of land liable therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1028) 
Sec. 22-9. - Assessments payable in cash. 
Assessment in conformity to appraisement and apportionment as confirmed by the city shall be payable to the treasurer of the city, and if paid within thirty (30) days from the date of the passage of the ordinance without interest. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1029) 
Sec. 22-10. - Assessments payable in installments; interest rate. 
In the event the owner of the land or of any street railway assessed shall, within thirty (30) days from the passage of the ordinance making the assessment final, file with the city clerk his or its written request asking that assessment be payable in installments in accordance with the provisions hereof; they shall thereupon be and become payable in equal annual installments over such period of years, not less than two (2) nor more than five (5), as shall be fixed and prescribed by the mayor and council, and the installments shall bear interest at a rate of not exceeding nine (9) percent per annum until paid and each installment together with the interest on the entire amount remaining unpaid shall be payable each year to the treasurer of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1030) 
Sec. 22-11. - Additional assessments. 
In the event any special assessment shall be found to be invalid or insufficient in whole or in part for any reason whatsoever, the mayor and council may at any time, in the manner provided for the making of an original assessment, proceed to cause a new assessment to be made and fixed, which shall have like force and effect as an original assessment. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1031) 
Sec. 22-12. - Lien of assessment. 
A special assessment and each installment thereof, and the interest thereon and the expense of collection, are hereby declared to be a lien against the lots and tracts of land so assessed from the date of the ordinance levying them, coequal with the lien of other taxes and prior to and superior to all other liens against these lots or tracts, and this lien shall continue until this assessment and interest thereon shall be fully paid, and shall be enforced in the same manner as are liens for city taxes. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1032) 
Sec. 22-13. - Execution, levy and sale. 
It shall be the duty of the treasurer, promptly within fifteen (15) days after the date of the maturity of any installment or assessment or interest, to issue an execution against the lot or tract of land assessed for this improvement, or against the party or person owing it, for the amount of this assessment or interest, and shall turn it over to the city marshal and/or the sheriff of the county or his deputies, who shall enforce the execution as provided by law. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1033) 
Chapter 23 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Numbering of structures, § 6-1; damaging painting, etc. as advertising matter on sidewalks, § 13-56; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 14; special assessments, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Removal of obstructions from streets; notice; noncompliance by owner. 
It shall be the duty of the code enforcement officer to notify the owner of any building upon any of the streets of the city, who may have erected adjacent to or in front of the building any structure, shed, posts, steps or other obstruction, upon inspection found by him to be decayed or in a dangerous condition, to remove them within five (5) days, and if at the expiration of this time the owner of the building, shed or other obstruction shall fail to have it removed, it shall be the duty of the code enforcement officer to proceed forthwith to have the shed, structure, fence or other obstruction in the public streets, removed by the street force of the city, at the expense of the owner thereof. It shall be the duty of the code enforcement officer, upon refusal of the owner to pay the amount of cost and expense incurred in this removal, to report it to the city treasurer, who shall issue executions therefor against this owner. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1034) 
Sec. 23-2. - Responsibility of abutting owner, occupant. 
It shall be the duty of every person owning or having in charge any real estate which fronts or abuts upon any sidewalk in the city, when notified by the code enforcement officer, to remove within five (5) days any dirt, sand, gravel or other substances that may be placed, or may accumulate upon, the sidewalk. 
(Code 1977, § 10-2007) 
Sec. 23-3. - Charitable contributions allowed. 
As provided by Official Code of Georgia Annotated Sec. 40-6-97.1, the chief of police is authorized to issue permits for the solicitation of contributions on city streets under the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Permits shall be issued only to charitable organizations registered with the State of Georgia or to charitable organizations which are exempt from such registration, as provided by the said state law; 
(2)  Applicants shall be required to execute a waiver and release of liability, holding the city harmless from any injury which may occur during such solicitation; 
(3)  No permit shall be issued when the charitable event is proposed to be held within six hundred (600) feet of an existing commercial entity engaged in a business which is the same as or similar to the proposed charitable event; and 
(4)  A permit shall be valid for fourteen (14) days. 
(Ord. No. 59-96, § 1, 8-5-96) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 59-96, § 1, adopted Aug. 5, 1996, repealed §§ 23-3 and 23-4, which pertained to fund raising on streets and encroachment upon, obstruction of, solicitation on public streets and roads. Said ordinance enacted new provisions which are included herein as 23-3. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 23-4. - Reserved. 
Note— See the editor's note at § 23-3. 
Sec. 23-5. - Street names. 
The street name listing as prepared by the city clerk's office in cooperation with the United States Postal Service and the 911 emergency system is adopted as the official street name listing for all streets within the corporate limits of this city. This listing shall be the official street name index for all city rights-of-way. The current street name listing will be kept in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 61-89, § 1, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 29-93, § 1, 4-19-93) 
Secs. 23-6—23-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 23-26. - Cutting, digging, etc., in public street—Permission required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, break, dig in or otherwise disturb any public street or alley in the city, or the surface thereof, without first having obtained permission therefor from the city engineer. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1001) 
Sec. 23-27. - Same—Regulations. 
It shall be unlawful for any public utility concern, contractor, plumber, city employee or other person having the permission required by section 23-26, to cut, break, dig in or otherwise disturb any public street or alley in the city, or the surface thereof, without complying with the following regulations: 
(1)  Notice shall first be given to the city engineer of the exact location of this work, the approximate time at which this work will be commenced, the probable length of time this work will require and the approximate length of time that this street or alley will remain cut, broken or otherwise disturbed before its repair; and if this work will be ofsuch character or of such extent that the movement of traffic over or along this street or alley will be hampered, impeded or stopped, a similar notice shall likewise be given the chief of police and the fire chief. 
(2)  Any such street or alley disturbance which constitutes a traffic hazard or other dangerous condition shall at all times be sufficiently barricaded or guarded adequately to protect the public and at night shall be properly and adequately lighted by the maintenance of sufficient lanterns, pot-torches or other appropriate lights upon, along or beside the disturbance (these lights to be placed and maintained at intervals or not more than thirty (30) feet along the entire length and breadth of the disturbance). 
(3)  In all cases where a public street is completely blocked or barricaded within the city, all traffic shall be adequately directed and detoured by means of appropriate signs and, when needed, guards shall be provided in order to direct traffic around the barricade so as to avoid confusion and unnecessary inconvenience to the traveling public. 
(4)  No closing of any lane of any public street shall be allowed between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., or between the hours of 3:30 p.m. and 6:00 p.m., on weekdays. 
(5)  No such lanes shall be allowed to be closed within one hundred (100) feet of an inoperable signalized intersection unless at least one (1) off-duty city law enforcement officer has been hired, through the office of the chief of police, at least one (1) week in advance of the date needed, to manually direct traffic through said intersection. 
(6)  No lane closings shall be allowed to remain overnight while unattended by personnel. 
(7)  None of the provisions of subsections (1), (3), (4) and (5) of this section shall be applicable to emergency repairs necessitated by any accident or natural disaster, nor to improvement projects under the Houston County Local Maintenance and Improvement Grant 2013; provided, however, that notice of any such repairs or projects shall be given to the chief of police immediately upon commencement of such work. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1002; Ord. No. 12-08, §§ 1, 2, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 07-11, § 1, 4-18-11; Ord. No. 15-13, § 1, 5-6-13) 
Sec. 23-28. - Refilling excavations in streets. 
The refilling of excavations in the streets will be accomplished in accordance with city specifications. 
(Code 1977, § 4-1003) 
Secs. 23-29—23-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARADE AND PUBLIC ASSEMBLY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, adopted Apr. 16, 2012, repealed the former Arts. III and IV, §§ 23-46—23-100, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to picketing and derived from Code 1977, §§ 7-2001—7-2003; Ord. No. 23-10, § 1, adopted May 3, 2010; and Ord. No. 41-11, § 1, adopted Nov. 21, 2011. The former Art. IV pertained to parades and derived from Code 1977, §§ 7-2006—7-2017. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 23-46. - Purpose and intent. 
The City of Warner Robins recognizes and supports the public's right of assembly and free speech and to utilize designated public facilities for such purposes. At the same time, the city has an important and compelling governmental interest in protecting property, public safety, health and welfare, and controlling use of streets and other public facilities and venues. This article seeks to accommodate public rights of speech and assembly consistent with that governmental interest by establishing procedures, terms, and conditions for use of public areas and facilities for such purposes. A second purpose of this article is to facilitate and manage the manner in which public facilities that are not otherwise required for governmental operations may be made available for use on a temporary basis for non-governmental operations. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-47. - Scope; authority. 
This article applies to all public parades and assemblies that may be expected to affect the public, the property or services of the city, to otherwise require an expenditure of time and expenses or create the potential for liability or public disturbance or other substantial concern. This article also applies to requests for use of public facilities for purposes other than governmental operations. This article is adopted in accordance with the authority vested in the city by its Charter, Article IX, Section II, Paragraphs II and III of the Georgia Constitution, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3 and all other applicable state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-48. - Definitions. 
In this article, words have their normal meanings, except as defined elsewhere in this Code or in this article as follows: 
Administrator means the person designated by section 23-49 to administer this article. 
City means the City of Warner Robins, Georgia. 
Parade means any march, procession or motorcade consisting of persons, animals, or vehicles, or a combination thereof, upon the streets, parks or other public grounds within the city with an intent of attracting public attention, if thirty (30) or more persons are involved, or that affects or may reasonably be expected to significantly affect the normal flow or regulation of vehicular or pedestrian traffic upon the streets, parks, or other public grounds. 
Permit means permission for assembly, parade, or use of public facilities issued pursuant to this article. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
Police chief means the chief of police of the city or the chief's designee. 
Public assembly means any meeting, demonstration, picket line, rally or gathering of thirty (30) or more persons for a common purpose as a result of prior planning that occupies any public facility or public area in a place open to the general public. 
Public facility means a building, structure, park, place or other location or area owned or operated by the city. 
Sidewalk means any area or way set aside or open to the general public for purposes of pedestrian traffic, whether paved or not. 
Street means any place or way set aside or open to the general public for purposes of vehicular traffic, including any berm or shoulder, parkway, right-of-way, or median strip thereof. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-49. - Administration; permit required. 
(a)  Administration. This article shall be administered by the police chief or that person's designee. The administrator may delegate functions related to facility use request or parade/public assembly requests to other persons but shall retain authority under the interim appeal process established by section 23-62. 
(b)  Permit requirement. Except as provided in this article, no person may engage in or conduct any parade or public assembly or use any public facility for purposes other than governmental operations of the city unless that person has a current and valid permit issued in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-50. - General exceptions. 
(a)  Permit exceptions. Permits and prior approvals under this article are not required for: 
(1)  Funeral processions; or 
(2)  Spontaneous events involving a parade or public assembly occasioned by news or affairs coming into public knowledge within seven (7) days prior to such public assembly, provided that: 
a.  The event occurs on private property or a public area in a manner that does not unduly disrupt or inconvenience the public in the use of such area; and 
b.  The organizer or sponsor thereof provides written notice to the administrator and police chief at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the start of the of the parade or public assembly, or such other prior notice as may be reasonable under the circumstances. 
(b)  Fees, expense, or other exceptions. Permits shall be required for all other parades or public assemblies or for events seeking to use public facilities. Exceptions and waivers from requirements for payment of fees and expenses, proof of insurance, bonding, or other security may be approved solely in accordance with those sections of this article applicable to such activities or events. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-51. - General standards and procedures. 
(a)  Decision-making unrelated to content of expression. To achieve the purposes of this article without undue interference with protected rights of speech and assembly, decisions to issue, deny, or conditionally approve permits shall not be based on the content of a message associated with the event absent a compelling governmental interest. Notwithstanding that general standard, protections otherwise applicable to speech and assembly are limited and may not extend to speech or assembly that is intended to or has the result of causing public alarm, disruption, falsehood, or other form of expression that is not protected under the laws or constitution of this state or the United States. 
(b)  Time, place and manner controls. This article seeks to impose reasonable time, place and manner controls in an appropriate and limited manner upon events and facility uses for which permits are required. This article shall be administered in a manner that seeks to allow for expression, assembly, and the exercise of religious rights in accordance with applicable constitutional and statutory limits and controls. 
(c)  Internal appeal step. At any point in the permit application and approval process, an applicant who feels aggrieved or substantially and adversely affected by compliance with the article or permit process may request review through an intermediate appeal procedure under section 23-62. 
(d)  General application time frame. Except for permits involving streets, facilities, or venues, or types of events identified for either expedited processing or requiring longer-term processing as identified in section 23-53 or elsewhere in this article, application for permits shall be filed not less than seven (7) days nor more than ninety (90) days, before the event for which the permit is sought. 
(e)  Requirements for insurance, bonding or other security. To avoid interference with protected rights of speech and assembly, any requirement imposed for surety for performance (including but not limited to insurance, bonding, or monetary deposits) shall be based upon needs directly associated with the event and not on the basis of possible disruption of the event by protestors or other persons who might be opposed to the speech or assembly. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-52. - Standard application process. 
(a)  The process set forth in this section includes the standard procedure and requirements that apply to all applications for permits under this article. Additional requirements and exceptions or waivers for specific types of permits are set forth in divisions 2 and 3 of this article. 
(b)  The administrator shall create and provide application forms for each type of permit required by this article. The information required by the application shall be the minimum information that is required of any applicant. The application form shall include information designed to allow the city to act on the application in an informed manner to determine if the application meets the requirements of this article including potential adverse effects as stated herein, and to allow the city to determine what requirements, if any, should be imposed as a condition of issuance of the permit. The administrator may amend any application form in whole or in part on such notice as is deemed appropriate under the circumstances, provided that an amendment shall not apply to an application made prior to the administrator's formal notice of any proposed amendment to the application form. 
(c)  Without limiting the authority of the administrator to require reasonable additional information in connection with any specific application, such forms shall require the applicant to identify: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person or the agent or representative of an organization or entity seeking to obtain the permit. 
(2)  The names, addresses, and telephone numbers of the headquarters or business location of the organization seeking the permit or organizing or sponsoring the event or activity, if any, and the authorized and responsible heads of the organization. 
(3)  If the application is filed by any person other than an individual applying on the individual's own behalf, the application shall include written authorization from that other person or from a responsible, legally authorized representative of an organizational applicant authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on its behalf. 
(4)  The requested date, time, and location for the event or activity. 
a.  The location description also shall identify the content of the public and private areas that will be involved in the activity or event. 
b.  The time shall include the time during which the event or activity will be conducted and the time(s) during which preparation, set-up, assembly, clean-up or other actions may occur. 
(5)  The approximate number of persons who are anticipated to attend or participate in the activity or event, including a separate list of the number of any anticipated spectators, protestors, or counter-demonstrators, as appropriate. 
(6)  A description of the activity or event, including a description of specific activities planned during the event. 
(7)  A description of any recording equipment, sound amplification equipment, banners, signs, or other attention-getting signs or devices to be used in connection with the event. 
(8)  A description of any additional public facilities or equipment to be utilized in connection with the event. 
(d)  Any person seeking a permit shall file a completed application with the administrator within the time frame required by this article or as stated on the application form, whichever time provides greater opportunity for review of the application by the city. The application shall be signed by the applicant or the applicant's duly authorized representative or agent under oath or affirmation. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-53. - Expedited or extended application review. 
(a)  Upon request of an applicant, the administrator may agree to an expedited application review when the applicant demonstrates that compliance with the standard review process (1) is not required due to size, location, duration, or other appropriate factors, indicating that public safety, welfare, and convenience would not be affected by expedited review or (2) would substantially burden protected rights, including speech and assembly, as to matters of public concern and the expedited review process would allow reasonable review to address substantial matters of public safety, welfare, and convenience. 
(b)  Upon determining that the size, location, duration, or other appropriate factors that affect public safety, welfare, and convenience, require more intensive review of an application, the administrator, after notice to the applicant, may extend the standard review period by a time not to exceed forty-eight (48) hours. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-54. - Fees. 
(a)  A non-refundable application processing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to cover administrative costs of processing the permit application shall be paid to the city by the applicant when the application is filed. 
(b)  The city may require the applicant to pay rental fees, service charges, or costs incurred by the city in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-55. - Police protection; public works and other expenses. 
(a)  Police protection. 
(1)  If possible, without disruption of ordinary police services or compromise of public safety and welfare, regularly scheduled on-duty police personnel shall cover the event. The administrator shall seek review of any application which might require additional police personnel by the police chief. 
(2)  When reviewing an application, the police chief shall determine whether and to what extent additional police protection is reasonably necessary for the event for traffic control and public safety and welfare, including public convenience. The police chief shall base this decision on relevant criteria including, but not limited to, the size, location, duration, time and date of the event; the expected sale or serving of alcoholic beverages; the number of streets and intersections blocked; and the need to detour or preempt public travel and use of streets and sidewalks. 
(3)  The speech content of the event shall not be a factor in determining the amount of police protection necessary. 
(4)  If additional police protection for the event is deemed necessary by the police chief, he shall so inform the administrator and applicant. The applicant shall be responsible for bearing the cost of the additional police protection deemed necessary by the police chief. The chief may, but is not required to, approve use of private security details, to be paid for by the applicant, in lieu of any or all special detail city police services that might otherwise be required under this section. 
(b)  Public works. In the same manner, the city shall determine if the applicant shall be required to pay for or provide additional public works-related actions such as lighting, refuse receptacle and pick-up, sanitary facilities, traffic control signs, devices, or personnel. 
(c)  Other expenses. In circumstances where the event itself may be expected to cause the city to incur additional, extraordinary expenses, the administrator shall identify such expenses and the basis for determining them to be extraordinary. Such expenses may be imposed upon the applicant as a condition of approval of the permit. 
(d)  Expense exception. An applicant for an event conducted for the sole purpose of public issue speech protected under the First Amendment or the Georgia Constitution as determined by the administrator shall not be required to pay for police protection or public works or other expense for actions provided by the city. However, the applicant shall obtain a permit as required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-56. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23-57. - Standards for action on application. 
In addition to standards applicable to particular events or activities under other provisions of this article, a permit shall be issued when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, the administrator finds that: 
(1)  The application is complete and sets forth accurately and in sufficient detail the information required for consideration. 
(2)  Conduct of the event will not unduly inconvenience either the public in using public areas normally open for general public use or the city in the conduct of governmental operations. 
(3)  Adequate sanitation and other required health facilities are or will be made available in or adjacent to the area in which the event will be held. 
(4)  There are sufficient parking places near the site of the event to accommodate the number of vehicles reasonably expected. 
(5)  The applicant has secured or provided for the cost of additional police protection or otherwise arranged for event security, if any, as may be required under section 23-55. 
(6)  The application has paid or provided for payment of any expenses or costs as may be required under section 23-55. 
(7)  No event is scheduled elsewhere in the city where city resources (including but not limited to law enforcement, fire, or public works personnel) required for the events are so great that their deployment would have an immediate and adverse effect upon the welfare and safety of persons and property. 
(8)  No permit may be issued that allows for the erection or placement of any structure, whether permanent or temporary, on a city street, sidewalk, or right-of-way unless advance approval for the erection or placement of the structure is obtained from the city council or administrator or other appropriate official or agency. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-58. - Non-discrimination. 
The administrator shall uniformly consider each application upon its merits and shall not discriminate in granting or denying permits under this article based upon political, religious, ethnic, race, disability, sexual orientation or gender-related grounds or other criteria that would constitute a violation of state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-59. - Recurring events; continuing permits. 
Regularly held and scheduled events that would otherwise require issuance of a permit under this article may receive longer-term approvals, not to exceed three (3) years in duration that will constitute permit approval under this article. Such longer-term approvals may be issued if the administrator finds that: 
(1)  The location for the events is in a place that has been approved for such purpose by site plan review (or its equivalent) by the planning board or otherwise is approved as a location for the events by the administrator; and 
(2)  The police chief, fire chief and public works director each have reviewed the location and schedule for the proposed events and have notified the administrator that they have no objection to the conduct of the events according to the schedule proposed. 
(3)  Any approvals under this section shall be subject to modification or termination upon a determination by the administrator of changed conditions, circumstances or needs of the city. Any such determination shall be subject to the appeal process under section 23-62 and shall not prevent the applicant from applying for a permit under other provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-60. - Administrative action on application. 
(a)  Upon receiving an application, the administrator shall determine within twenty-four (24) hours if the application is complete or if any additional preliminary information is required and shall so inform the applicant. The applicant shall provide such required information prior to further consideration of the application. The requirement to supplement the application at this stage does not prevent the city from requiring additional information during its review and action upon the application. 
(b)  After accepting an application, the administrator shall forward it for review and recommendation to the police chief and to any other city employee, official or board deemed appropriate. Such review and recommendation shall occur within three (3) days unless that period is extended by the administrator. 
(c)  The administrator also may refer the application for review by other governmental entities (e.g. county, regional or state authorities) as deemed appropriate. 
(d)  After receiving comments and recommendations from such reviews and after considering such other information as deemed appropriate, the administrator may require the applicant to submit additional information or respond to the reviews and recommendations or impose such conditions as are appropriate under the circumstances. 
(e)  Upon completion of the foregoing, the administrator shall act on the application. The administrator may approve, amend, approve with conditions, or deny the application. For any action other than approval as submitted, the administration shall include a brief summary of the reasons for the decision. 
(f)  Unless otherwise provided in this article or agreed to by the applicant, the administrator shall act on an application within five (5) days after determining that the application is complete in accordance with paragraph (a) of this section. If a completed application has been submitted in a timely manner, the administrator shall in any event act upon the application and provide notice to the applicant in accordance with section 23-57 no later than two (2) days prior to the event. 
(g)  The administrator may authorize the conduct of the event at a date, time, location, or route different from that proposed by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept such an alternate permit shall so notify the administrator in writing not less than three (3) days after notice of the administrator's action, or, if less than five (5) days remain before the event after notice of the administrator's action, within twenty-four (24) hours. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of, a permit issued under this article. 
(h)  A person aggrieved and directly affected by a decision of the administrator under the section may file an interim or final administrative appeal pursuant to section 23-62. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-61. - Notice of action on application. 
The administrator shall act upon a timely filed application for permit in accordance with section 23-60. The administrator shall notify the applicant of action on the application either by personal delivery or certified mail at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the event. If the application is denied, approved with conditions, or otherwise modified, the notice shall include a statement of the reason(s) for such action. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-62. - Interim and final appeals. 
An applicant or other person who is directly affected by a decision of the administrator under this article may file an appeal of the decision as provided in this section. 
(1)  Interim appeal. Prior to a final decision by the administrator, an applicant who claims that delay, imposition of conditions, or other action by the city violates any applicable law or unreasonably and improperly interferes with constitutionally protected rights, may file an interim appeal as follows: 
a.  The applicant shall notify the administrator in writing of the claim specifying in detail the basis for the claim. The administrator shall review the notice and determine if administrative action will adequately resolve the problem. 
b.  If the applicant is not satisfied by such administrative action, the applicant may file a written appeal within forty-eight (48) hours to the mayor, with a copy to the city clerk specifying the grounds for the appeal. The mayor shall review the appeal to determine if he will hear the matter or if he/she determines that grounds for appeal are not properly set forth. 
c.  If the mayor determines that the appeal will not be heard, he/she shall notify the applicant within twenty-four (24) hours of such decision. If the appeal proceeds, the mayor shall schedule a hearing on the matter within two (2) days with such notice to the applicant as is deemed appropriate under the circumstances. At the hearing, the mayor shall hear the applicant, administrator, and such other persons as may be allowed to speak. Within forty-eight (48) hours after the hearing, the mayor shall issue his/her decision in writing and shall so notify the applicant. 
(2)  Appeal of final action. The applicant or any person directly affected by final administrative action on an application may file a written appeal with the city council with a copy to the city clerk no later than three (3) days after the final action. The appeal shall state with specificity the grounds for the appeal. The city council may deny an appeal without a hearing if it determines on the face of the appeal (within fourteen (14) days of the filing of the appeal) that it has no merit and shall so notify the applicant and other directly affected parties within forty-eight (48) hours after such determination. If the appeal proceeds, the city council shall schedule a hearing within fourteen (14) days of the filing of the appeal. The appeal hearing shall be limited to the grounds stated in the appeal unless the city council for good cause determines to hear other issues or concerns. The appellant/applicant (if not the appellant), the administrator and other persons directly affected may speak or submit evidence at the hearing. The city council may determine who is permitted to participate in the hearing. The city council shall issue its decision on the appeal, stating the reasons for its decision, within five (5) days after the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-63. - Duties of permittees. 
(a)  A permittee shall comply with all requirements of this article, all permit terms and conditions, and all applicable laws and ordinances in effect at the time of the event. 
(b)  The individual identified in the application as the agent or representative of the applicant/permittee, or some other person designated in the permit, shall have the permit in his or her possession at all times during the event for which the permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-64. - General prohibitions. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any person: 
(1)  To stage, present, or conduct any event for which a permit is required by this article without first having obtained a permit; 
(2)  To participate in an event which that person knows is required to have a permit under this article when that permit has not been issued; or 
(3)  When the person is the permittee, or an agent or representative of a permittee, to knowingly fail to comply with any term of condition of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
DIVISION 2. - PARADES AND PUBLIC ASSEMBLIES 

Sec. 23-65. - Applicability. 
This subdivision applies to parades and public assemblies. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-66. - Application time frames. 
(a)  Unless otherwise allowed by the administrator, an application for a parade permit shall be made within the following time periods: 
(1)  At least thirty (30) days prior to the event date for arterial streets (as that term is defined in the city's subdivision ordinance) and events expected to involve more than one hundred (100) individuals. 
(2)  At least fourteen (14) days for all other streets and events expected to involve one hundred (100) or fewer individuals. 
(b)  Whenever an applicant believes that the time normally required for action on a permit under paragraph (a) will interfere with protected rights of speech or assembly or would render ineffective the purpose for which the event is proposed, the applicant shall include in the application a written request for expedited review, including a description of the basis therefore. The administrator shall promptly review such request and, unless it is determined that cause for expedited review is not stated, shall grant expedited review within such time as may be reasonably required to meet the purposes of this article. If the administrator determines that expedited review is not appropriate, a written decision shall be issued stating the reasons for that decision. A denial of expedited review may be reviewed using the interim [no reference to an "expedited" appeal in section 23-62] appeal process under section 23-62. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-67. - Parade or public assembly permit application. 
In addition to the information and materials contained in a general permit application under this article, unless waived by the administrator, an application for a parade or public assembly permit shall include the following: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person or organization seeking to conduct such parade or public assembly; 
(2)  The names, addresses, and telephone numbers of the headquarters of the organization for which the parade or public assembly is to be conducted, if any, and the authorized and responsible heads of the organization; 
(3)  The route to be traveled including the starting point and the termination point; 
(4)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade or public assembly, and the type of animals and description of the vehicles; 
(5)  The hours when such parade or public assembly will start and terminate; 
(6)  A statement as to whether the parade or public assembly will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets and/or sidewalks to be traversed; 
(7)  The location by street of any assembly areas for such parade or public assembly and a description of facilities to be used for parking of participants' vehicles; 
(8)  The time at which units of the parade or public assembly will begin to assemble at any such area; 
(9)  The type of public assembly, including a description of activities planned during the event; 
(10)  A description of any recording equipment, sound amplification equipment, banners, signs, or other attention-getting devices to be used in connection with the parade or public assembly; 
(11)  The approximate number of participants in addition to the number provided in subsection (4) above, if any (spectators are not deemed to be participants); 
(12)  The approximate number of spectators expected; 
(13)  A description of any public facilities or equipment to be utilized; 
(14)  A description of sanitary and waste disposal facilities to be provided, if any; 
(15)  A description of any vending, food service, or other similar activities to be provided or allowed during or in association with the parade or public assembly; and 
(16)  Such other information as the administrator finds reasonably necessary or appropriate to make a determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-68. - Permit application; additional considerations. 
(a)  In determining whether to approve an application for a permit for a parade or public assembly, the administrator shall provide notice prior to action to the police and fire chiefs and the public works director. 
(b)  In determining whether to approve or deny an application for a permit for a parade or public assembly, the administrator shall consider the following additional factors: 
(1)  The potential for the parade or public assembly to substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other pedestrian or vehicular traffic contiguous to its route or location. 
(2)  The potential for the parade or public assembly to require the diversion of so great a number of city police officers to properly police the event as to prevent normal police protection of the city. 
(3)  The potential for concentration of persons, animals, and vehicles at public assembly points of the parade or public assembly to unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to public assembly areas. 
(4)  The potential for the conduct of the parade or public assembly to cause injury to persons or property. 
(5)  Comments submitted by the officials and individuals listed in paragraph (a). 
(c)  Applications or permits for parades, public assemblies, or other events for reasonably contemporaneous times and proximate locations which might unduly inconvenience the public in the use of public facilities, or unreasonably strain public facilities or services, or otherwise have an immediate and adverse effect upon the welfare and safety of persons and property. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-69. - Contents of permit. 
(a)  Each parade or public assembly permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting and approximate ending time; 
(2)  Minimum speed of parade units; 
(3)  Maximum speed of parade units; 
(4)  The portions of the streets that may be occupied by the parade or public assembly; 
(5)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. 
(b)  A permit also shall contain such other information as the administrator deems appropriate for the purposes of this article, including any conditions or limitations upon exercise of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-70. - Notice of approved permit. 
(a)  Upon the issuance of a parade or public assembly permit, the administrator shall promptly send a copy of the permit to the police and fire chiefs; the mayor; the city attorney; and the director of the department of public works. 
(b)  A copy of any permit issued under this article shall be deemed a public record and shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-71. - Commercial parades or assemblies. 
(a)  Parades or public assembly permits that seek to utilize public facilities where the primary purpose of the event is to promote any products, goods or event that is primarily for private profit-making purposes may be approved only if: 
(1)  The public facility is not otherwise required for use for public purposes; 
(2)  All costs to the city, direct and indirect, are reimbursed in full by the sponsor of the event; and 
(3)  The application satisfies all other provisions of this article. 
(b)  The limitation on advertising and promotion of commercial products, goods or events shall not apply to signs identifying organizations or sponsors furnishing or sponsoring exhibits or structures used in a parade or public assembly conducted primarily by a not-for-profit organization or for a related purpose. 
(c)  The limitations set forth in this section is not intended to prevent assemblies or parades conducted for private, profit purposes that are conducted on private property in full accord with local land use and other ordinances and which incidentally may utilize public streets, sidewalks or other places. However, a permit must be obtained under this article for such incidental uses. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-72. - Specific prohibitions. 
In addition to any other prohibitions set forth in this article, the following prohibitions apply to permits for parades and public assemblies. No person may: 
(1)  Engage in any parade or public assembly activity that would constitute a substantial hazard to the public safety or that would materially interfere with or endanger the public peace or rights of residents to the quiet and peaceful enjoyment of their property. 
(2)  Carry or possess any length of metal, lumber, wood, or similar material for purposes of displaying a sign, poster, plaque or notice, unless such object is one-fourth-inch or less in thickness and two (2) inches or less in width or if not generally rectangular in shape, such object shall not exceed three-fourths-inch in its thickest dimension. 
(3)  Carry any sign, poster, plague, or notice, whether or not mounted on a length of material as specified in paragraph (2), unless such sign, poster, plaque, or notice is constructed or made of cloth, paper, or cardboard material. 
(4)  Utilize sound amplification equipment or noise levels that violate applicable city ordinance(s) or that otherwise causes substantial interference with public health and welfare so as to cause a public nuisance. 
(5)  Ride, drive, or cause to be ridden or driven any animal-drawn vehicle upon any public street, unless specifically authorized by the permit. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-73. - Public conduct during parades or public assemblies. 
(a)  No person may unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede, or interfere with any parade or public assembly or with any person, vehicle, or animal participating or used in a parade or public assembly. 
(b)  No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade or public assembly when such vehicles or person are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade or public assembly. 
(c)  The police chief (or other appropriate board or official), when reasonably necessary, may prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a street constituting a part of the route or location of a parade or public assembly. The police chief (or other board or official) shall post signs to that effect. Any person who parks or leaves a vehicle unattended in violation of such requirement in a posted area shall be guilty of a violation (or other offense) in accordance with city parking ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-74. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - USE OF PUBLIC FACILITIES FOR NON-PUBLIC EVENTS 

Sec. 23-75. - Applicability. 
This division applies to events intended to utilize public facilities for events to which the general public is not invited or expected to attend or for purposes other than the exercise of First Amendment rights of speech or assembly. 
(1)  A person or organization may apply for a permit to use public facilities for such private events, including but not limited to: 
a.  Social events such as parties, celebrations, weddings, and reunions. 
b.  Education, civic, and cultural events. 
c.  Political events. 
d.  Religious purposes. 
(2)  An application for such event shall conform to all other requirements for permits under this article and also shall contain the following information: 
a.  Purpose of the event. 
b.  Nature of the use to be made of the facility. 
c.  Food and beverages to be served at or in connection with the event. 
d.  Whether the event is open to the public, invited guests, or others, including a description of any individuals or organizations to whom entry to the event may be denied. 
e.  Whether an admission fee or other charge will be imposed. 
(3)  The administrator shall utilize the general standards under this article to determine if a permit for such use shall be granted and also shall consider the following factors: 
a.  Such use shall not be inconsistent with the general public standards extant in the city. 
b.  The possibility of damage to or destruction of city property. 
c.  Existing use regulations or practices for the facility which would be inconsistent with the proposed event. 
d.  The likelihood that granting permission for the use would reflect adversely on the city. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-76. - Rental fees. 
In addition to the application fee and other charges that may be imposed for a permit under this article, the applicant for a permit under this subdivision shall pay rental fees for the facility as hereinafter set forth. 
(1)  Rental fees shall be payable according to the schedule set by the city and available at the city clerk's office. 
(2)  Rental fees may be decreased or waived if the administrator determines that the event will be conducted in a manner that serves the public interest or where imposition of the fee would pose a substantial burden on the exercise of the First Amendment rights of speech or assembly. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-77. - Religious uses. 
Permits for use of public facilities for religious purposes may be issued but the administrator shall act on permit applications so that: 
(1)  There is no appearance of support for or establishment of a sectarian religious purpose. 
(2)  Selection of applicants is not based on discrimination based on religious belief. 
(3)  Individuals and organizations are given reasonable opportunities to use public facilities. This requirement shall not be deemed to prohibit the rental of public facilities for extended periods for the conduct of regular religious services. 
(4)  Any religious images, decorations, or other publicity or display are temporary and used solely during periods of rental and are removed during other periods. 
(5)  The administrator may require users to post notices to the effect that the allowed use is not deemed an endorsement of the user or the user's beliefs by the city. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-78. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 23-79. - Participation in event; restrictions. 
(a)  Participation. An event for which a permit is issued to a private entity that is not part of the local government of the city or an event that is not sponsored directly or indirectly by the city shall not be deemed state or governmental action. Accordingly, the city shall not compel or otherwise direct the inclusion or exclusion in the event of any group or class of individuals. 
(b)  Restrictions on participation. An event subject to this article may be limited as to the number of participants in the interest of safety, health, public order, and adequacy of facilities and security. If the number of participants is so limited, the permit shall specify an objective manner in which participants are selected and shall provide an expedited manner of appealing any exclusion in accordance with section 23-62. The number of participants also may be restricted by order of the administrator or police chief or fire chief, even if not limited in the permit, based on considerations of public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-80. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23-81. - Cost recovery. 
If a permittee fails to pay costs or take actions required under this article, the city, after requesting the permittee for payment, may seek to recover such costs from the permittee or other responsible person by appropriate legal action. If the city prevails in any such action for recovery, it shall be entitled to reimbursement of any costs incurred in seeking such recovery, including court costs and attorney's fees. Cost recovery from permittees and participants shall be focused upon the conduct of the permittees and authorized participants and not on conduct of observers or others over whom permittee cannot reasonably be expected to exercise control. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-82. - Revocation or suspension of permit. 
(a)  The administrator may suspend or revoke any permit issued under this article upon finding any violation of this article, the terms or conditions imposed in the permit, or for any other action deemed detrimental to public health and safety. Such revocation shall take effect immediately, and the administrator shall promptly notify the permittee of revocation. After revocation, the permittee may not conduct the event, or if the event has commenced, shall immediately cause the event to be terminated in a safe and proper manner. 
(b)  If a public emergency arises where city resources required for the emergency are so great that deployment of city personnel, equipment or services for a parade or public assembly would have an immediate, adverse effect upon welfare and safety of persons or property, the administrator may suspend or revoke the permit and the permittee shall comply with such directives as the administrator may impose. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-83. - Enforcement. 
This article may be enforced by injunction, restraining order, declaratory relief or such other order as may be imposed by a court with appropriate jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-84. - Violations/penalties. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate this article or to violate or deviate from the terms or conditions of any permit issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-85. - Judicial review. 
Any person aggrieved by a decision under this article may appeal from that decision to a court with appropriate jurisdiction in accordance with applicable statutes or court rules. Any person who is granted standing to file administrative appeals pursuant to section 23-62 shall first exhaust such administrative remedies prior to seeking judicial relief. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 23-86. - Severability. 
If any provision of this article is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-12, §§ 1, 2, 4-16-12) 
Chapter 24 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; utility fees payable when building permit issued, § 6-35; special assessments, ch. 22; excavations, § 23-26 et seq. 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; municipal utilities, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Definition. 
In this article "utility service" or "utility" means the city's gas, water, sewage collection and disposal or solid waste collection and disposal systems or services, or any combination of same. 
Sec. 24-2. - Services outside the city; conditions. 
(a)  Gas, water, sewer. No water, sewer or gas service shall be furnished to property outside the city until the following items have been complied with and approved by the mayor and council: 
(1)  Approval of preliminary plans. Approval of preliminary plans for subdivision by the appropriate governmental authority which plan shall include the following: 
a.  Water system including size of main; 
b.  Sanitary sewer system including all trunk lines and lateral lines; 
c.  Proposed street names; 
d.  Type of street paving; 
e.  Provision for adequate curbs and gutters; 
f.  Installation of storm sewers where needed; and 
g.  Proposed playground or park area; if any. 
(2)  Contract required. Before any water, sewage or gas utilities will be furnished to properties outside the city, it shall be necessary that the city and contractor enter into a contract relative to the accomplishment of the items heretofore outlined. 
(b)  Utilities. 
(1)  When a property owner requests utility services to property not within the corporate limits of the city, at the discretion of the city, the owner will be required to: 
a.  Petition for annexation (if the property is contiguous to the existing limits of the city) prior to commencement of construction of utility lines; or 
b.  Execute a restrictive covenant consenting to annexation of such property into the city when the property becomes contiguous. 
(2)  When such property is not contiguous and execution of the covenant is required, the owner will also be required to submit a certificate of title to the city attorney's office to verify ownership of the property. The covenant will be recorded in the property records at the county courthouse and will stipulate that if the property becomes contiguous in the future and the property owner refuses to petition for annexation, the city will have the authority to terminate utility services. 
(3)  Construction of utility lines will not begin until the requirements of this policy are met, which shall be indicated by authorization of the mayor. 
Any connection of utility services to a property outside the corporate limits of the city must be approved in advance by a formal vote of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1977, §§ 5-1002, 5-1002.1; Ord. No. 2-13, § 1, 2-19-13; Ord. No. 17-16, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 59-17, § 1, 12-14-17) 
Sec. 24-3. - Rules, regulations for extension of water, sewer service.[2] 
The city shall furnish water and sewer service to all users within economical reach of its water and sewer system in accordance with the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  Connection fee. All applications or contracts for service must be accompanied by the required connection fee before the connection will be made. 
(2)  Extensions to one hundred (100) feet. 
a.  To properties lying within the city limits. The city shall make necessary extensions of supply mains or sewers up to but not in excess of one hundred (100) feet, and will provide the required service line to property lines of customers. Exceptions to this provision may be made by the mayor in his/her discretion provided: 
1.  i.  The affected properties are within the city limits; or 
ii.  The affected properties are planned for annexation in accordance with a binding agreement between a developer/owner and the city; and 
2.  The total cost of the extension does not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for the sewerage lines and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for water lines. Any other exception to this policy must be evidenced by a written contract between the city and the developer/owner and approved by the mayor and council as is required by Charter for approval of all contracts. 
b.  To properties lying outside the city limits. The developer/owner shall be responsible for the full costs of any such extension. 
(3)  Service lines. Service lines on customers' property must be furnished by customers. 
(4)  Extensions in excess of one hundred feet; expenses; refunds. Extensions for water or sewer service in excess of one hundred (100) feet will be made for builders, developers or individuals only at their expense. The cost of these extensions must be paid at the time application or agreement for service is executed. Amounts advanced for these extensions may be refunded in accordance with the terms of the agreement but not in excess of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each customer connected to the line provided for the service. Refunds will be due and payable one (1) year from the date of agreement and annually thereafter until the amount advanced has been refunded, but not for a period in excess of five (5) years from the date of the agreement. 
(5)  Service to builders, subdividers, developers, conditions. The city will supply water and sewer service to builders, subdividers or developers when the facilities, exclusive of water meters, are constructed in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the city and paid for by the developers. Ownership of these facilities must be transferred to the city free and clear of all liens before connections are made and the city will operate and maintain the facilities thereafter as a part of the municipal water and sewer systems. 
(6)  Adjusting minimum charges. In cases where extensions are requested to service existing residences, but immediate revenues are less than twenty (20) percent of the cost of the extensions, the minimum charge for water or sewer service may be increased to justify the investment in the extension. These increased rates shall be reduced annually in direct proportion to the number of new customers added to the extended main but not less than the minimum rate established by the applicable schedule of rates then in effect. 
(7)  Sale of water for resale. The city shall not sell water to any customer for resale to others, except to other governmental agencies. 
(8)  Other extensions. Extensions not covered specifically by the foregoing regulations shall be made in general conformity to the overall policies established herein to the end that all transactions are fair and equitable to all customers of the city water and sewer department. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2002; Ord. No. 45-93, § 1, 8-2-93; Ord. No. 23-94, § 1, 4-18-94; Ord. No. 32-94, § 6, 7-18-94) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Note— A resolution adopted on Oct. 21, 2002, approved the Revised Water and Sewer Standards. The charge for the specifications will be $50.00 each. 

Sec. 24-4. - Unlawful use of city utilities; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to connect to the water, sewer or gas utilities systems of the city without first complying with all the rules, regulations and ordinances now applicable to tap-in, connection or service fees, and by placing the proper deposit for each of the services. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to reconnect to the public utility system of the city when the city has disconnected the utilities for nonpayment for services or utilities rendered. 
(c)  A violation of the above shall constitute a continuing daily crime against the city and shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by imprisonment in the city jail for a period of not more than one (1) year, or both, for each offense. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to disconnect any and all utilities furnished by the city if the applicant is in a delinquent status with the city for utilities furnished. 
(Code 1977, § 5-1004) 
Sec. 24-5. - Connecting or tampering with water and sewer mains. 
(a)  All meters, curb cocks, valves and meter boxes and other apparatus connected with the city's water and sewer mains and service pipes shall remain under the direct control of the utilities department and it shall be unlawful for persons other than those authorized by the utilities director to connect, disconnect or tamper with any such meter, or to turn off the water at the curb cock, valve or meter, or to open, move or tamper with any meter box or other apparatus connected with the city's water and sewer mains and lines. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an employee of the utilities department in the performance of his duties as such, to tap into or make any opening in any street in connection with the water or sewer mains or lines of the city, and any such taps or connections that require cutting in a public street shall comply with the provisions of chapter 23, article II. 
(Code 1977, § 5-1005) 
Sec. 24-6. - Utility service charges. 
(a)  When city employees disconnect gas and/or water meters at the request of the customer, service charges of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) shall be required for disconnection of the service and thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for the reconnection. In the discretion of the mayor or his designee, these charges may be waived for emergency or system repairs. Repeat trips to connect utility services, for the same work order, shall require a twenty-dollar service charge per trip. 
(b)  When city employees make a service trip to disconnect gas and/or water meters for delinquent bills a thirty-five-dollar service charge shall be applied. 
(c)  A service charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be required for a return trip, by city employees, to reread a utility meter when done at the customers request or due to inaccessibility to the meter because of a locked gate, shrubberies blocking meters and unfriendly pets, etc. 
(d)  Any check in payment for utility services returned because of insufficient funds, closed accounts, etc., shall be subject to a thirty-dollar handling fee. 
(e)  Transfer of gas and/or water utility service from one (1) location to another shall be subject to a twenty-five-dollar transfer fee. 
(f)  A service charge of sixty-five dollars ($65.00) shall be charged for the connection of service between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., Monday through Sunday, including holidays. 
(Code 1977, §§ 5-1001(c), 5-1006, 5-1008; Ord. No. 42-90, § 1, 7-2-90; Ord. No. 21-93, § 1, 3-15-93; Ord. No. 55-93, § 1, 10-18-93; Ord. No. 24-95, § 1, 4-17-95; Ord. No. 20-98, § 1, 3-2-98; Ord. No. 37-10, § 1, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 24-7. - Bills; penalty; disconnection. 
(a)  Bills to customers for utility services shall be mailed out on such day or days of each month as may be determined to be desirable and the amount due shall be payable in ten (10) days from the date thereof, and if not paid within fifteen (15) days of the date bills are mailed, a penalty of ten (10) percent of the amount of the bill shall be added thereto and collected. If the amount of the bill is not paid within twenty (20) days after the date the bill is rendered, all utility services shall be disconnected unless a prior agreement has been reached between the city and the utility customer. 
(b)  The mayor, at his discretion, may authorize the utility department to continue service for new owners of property where a lien exists if the new owners agree to an installment payment schedule with a period not to exceed twelve (12) months. Where the responsible party does not meet the agreed payment schedule services shall be discontinued. 
(Code 1977, § 5-1001(a), (b); Ord. No. 23-96, § 1, 4-1-96; Ord. No. 05-17, § 1, 2-21-17) 
Sec. 24-8. - Accessibility of meters. 
(a)  Utility customers shall maintain the area immediately surrounding meters free of debris, shrubbery, weeds, or tall grass so as to make such meter readily accessible to utility service personnel. Customers who do not meet the above requirements shall be subject to a thirty dollar ($30.00) administrative charge for each meter reading where utility service personnel find a violation, to compensate for additional efforts to read the meter. The customer shall be notified by first class mail that the requirements of this section have not been met, and such notice shall provide a minimum of ten (10) days' notice to the customer of the department's intention to impose the administrative charge at the next meter reading if the obstruction has not been removed. 
(b)  (1)  It shall be unlawful to obstruct, damage, or hide any water meter, or other water recording device, in such a manner that the meter reader or other employee of the utility department is unable to gain access. If the obstruction remains in place for two (2) days following notice of the violation, the owner, or person in legal control of the property, will be responsible for the administrative charge set forth in (a) above and any cost incurred by the department for the purpose of removing the obstruction. 
(2)  Repeated violations of this article will subject the customer to the maximum penalties set forth in section 1-7 of the City Code. 
(Code 1977, § 5-1001(d); Ord. No. 26-18, § 1, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 24-9. - Collection of delinquent water bills. 
(a)  The mayor and council may enforce the collection of delinquent charges for natural gas sales, water, sewerage, and sanitation services, by execution to be issued by the city clerk against the owners of the premises and such other persons as may be liable therefor, when such rents and charges are due and remain unpaid for a period of twenty (20) days. The execution shall become a lien upon the premises when recorded in the general execution docket of the county and shall be collected as a lien for city taxes. 
(b)  The mayor may, at his discretion, cause services, to present or subsequent owners, to be discontinued until the unpaid rents or charges are paid, or take other steps that he considers necessary to collect the delinquent charges or rents. 
(Code 1977, § 5-1011; Ord. No. 16-04, § 1, 4-5-04) 
Sec. 24-10. - [Activation fee.] 
(a)  For each new account established for city provided water and/or sewer service for residential customers, a non-refundable activation fee shall be charged on a one-time basis. This activation fee shall be set at sixty-five dollars ($65.00) per account. For each new account established for city provided water and/or sewer utility service for commercial customers, a non-refundable activation fee shall be charged on a one-time basis. This activation fee shall be set at eighty dollars ($80.00) per account. 
This activation fee will not be charged if one (1) or more of the below conditions exist: 
(1)  The customer is a local governmental entity, State of Georgia entity or federal agency. 
(2)  The customer is relocating from another city service location and no service/payment issue(s) have occurred within the prior twenty-four (24) months. 
(3)  The customer is a landlord/rental agent providing service on an account for no more than thirty (30) days. 
(b)  For mobile home parks, apartment complexes and multihousing units, an additional thirty-five-dollar activation fee shall be charged for each mobile home or apartment unit. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any of the above provisions, the owner of any multiple-family dwelling which is served by a single water meter shall be responsible for the payment of any and all activation fees required under this section and for payment of the water bill for the entire dwelling. In the alternative, at the election of the property owner, such owner shall be entitled to install, at such owner's sole expense, separate water meters to any or each of the units contained in such dwelling. For purposes of this section, multiple-family dwelling shall be defined as any single structure which contains separate and distinct living areas for two (2) or more family units. 
(d)  In the event any utility account becomes delinquent, the city shall, in the sole discretion of the mayor, or his/her designee, be authorized to require a security deposit of an amount equal to the sum of the total utility bills for the three (3) highest months within the year immediately preceding such delinquency. For purposes of this section only, an account shall be delinquent when it has, on two (2) or more occasions, remained unpaid on the twentieth day after billing and penalties have been assessed. 
(e)  For each new account established for city provided natural gas utility service for residential customers, a non-refundable activation fee shall be charged on a one-time basis. This activation fee shall be set at eighty-five dollars ($85.00) per account. For each new account established for city provided natural gas utility service for commercial customers, a non-refundable activation fee shall be charged on a one-time basis. This activation fee shall be set at one hundred dollars ($100.00) per account. 
(f)  Pilot lights. 
(1)  Except as provided below, a twenty-five-dollar fee shall be charged for the initial lighting of a pilot light by city employees. Any lighting of additional pilot lights on the same service call shall require the payment of a ten-dollar service fee per lighting. 
(2)  The fees for lighting a pilot light shall not be required when gas service has been interrupted by the city due to emergency or normal gas line maintenance. 
(3)  The fees for lighting pilot(s) shall not be required for new gas account customers. 
This activation fee will not be charged if one (1) or more of the below conditions exist: 
a.  The customer is a local governmental entity, State of Georgia entity or federal agency. 
b.  The customer is relocating from another city service location and no service/payment issue(s) have occurred within the prior twenty-four (24) months. 
(g)  For each new account established for a combination of city provided water, sewer and natural gas utility service for a single residential location/customer, a non-refundable activation fee shall be set at one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00). For each new account established for a combination of city provided water, sewer and natural gas utility service for a single commercial location/customer, a non-refundable activation fee shall be set at one hundred forty-four dollars ($144.00). 
(Ord. No. 37-10, § 1, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 24-11. - Tampering with utility equipment and theft of utility services. 
(a)  The following practices or acts are hereby declared to be illegal and are prohibited by the mayor and council of the City of Warner Robins. 
(1)  The cutting, removing or in any manner making ineffective any seal, locking band or lock on an electrical or natural gas meter. 
(2)  Restoration of service by any means after service has been terminated for nonpayment, or obtaining electricity or natural gas, without making the proper deposit with a utility company or receiving proper authorization from the respective utility company. 
(3)  Obtaining electricity or natural gas by use of jumper wires, or by any other means which bypass a metering device either partially or completely. 
(4)  Damaging or tampering in any manner with any part of a metering device belonging to a utility company. 
(5)  Changing or altering the normal installed position of a metering device in any fashion which causes the normal accurate recording of utility service received to be altered and inaccurate. 
(6)  Obtaining electricity or natural gas by use of a metering device which is not authorized by a utility company. 
(7)  Interfering with the automatic registration, recording and transmission of electricity or natural gas consumption when readings are recorded and/or transmitted electronically. 
(8)  Fraudulently obtaining, or attempting to obtain service from a utility company by using a false name or identification. 
(9)  Fraudulently obtaining, or attempting to obtain service from a utility company by placing the account in the name of someone else after the service has been disconnected for nonpayment or theft of service while the person in whose name the service was in when disconnected is still living at the location of the service; the utility company may refuse or discontinue service to an applicant in this case. 
(10)  Any other reception of electrical power or natural gas service without proper authorization from the respective utility company. 
(b)  Alleged violations of this section shall be tried in the Municipal Court of the City of Warner Robins. Any person found guilty of violating any section or part of this section shall be fined a sum not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) on each count. Each day that the violation continues is a separate count. 
(c)  Any person found violating any section or part of this section will be required to make full restitution to the utility company for the cost of the services obtained in violation of the section, for damage to equipment of a utility company and for all associated costs of the investigation. In calculating the amount of restitution to be paid, the court is authorized to consider the following evidence. 
(1)  The cost of the service received as a result of violating this section shall be computed by the utility company. 
(2)  The cost of any damage to utility equipment shall be based on the actual costs. Costs may be computed and updated annually. 
(3)  Investigative and any associated costs will be computed and updated annually by the utility company. 
(d)  Any person in possession of any premises as owner, occupant, or tenant who is found to have an electric or natural gas meter which has been tapered with or altered in violation of this section or found to be receiving electricity or natural gas as a result of any of the methods described above shall be presumed to have knowingly violated the terms of this section. Such receipt of electricity of natural gas shall be deemed prima facie evidence of intent to defraud or deprive the utility company of recovering proper charges for payment for such service. 
(e)  All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed to the extent of said conflict. 
(f)  That the provisions of this section are hereby declared to be severable, and if any section, phrase or provision shall be declared or held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the remainder of the sections, phrases or provisions.
