(g)  The mayor and council find that there is a continuing problem by individuals' illegally obtaining electricity and natural gas service by various means and that this results in a loss of revenue to utility companies, increased costs to other consumers and creates a dangerous situation that can result in the loss of life or property. 
(h)  This section shall be cumulative to O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25, and is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25(c) which states: 
O.C.G.A. 16-7-25 Damaging, injuring, or interfering with property of public utility companies, municipalities, or political subdivisions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful or any person intentionally and without authority to injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, post, lamp, or other apparatus belonging to a company, municipality, or political subdivision engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, telephone, or other public services; intentionally and without authority to prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of such service supplied; in any way to interfere with the proper action of such company, municipality, or political subdivision; intentionally to divert any services of such company, municipality, or political subdivision; or otherwise intentionally and without authority to use or cause to be used, without the consent of the company, municipality, or political subdivision, any service manufactured, sold or distributed by the company, municipality, or political subdivision. 
(b)  Where there is no evidence to the contrary, the person performing any of the illegal acts set forth in subsection (a) of this Code section and the person who with knowledge of such violation receives the benefit of such service without proper charge as a result of the improper action shall be presumed to be responsible for the act of tampering or diversion. 
(c)  This Code section shall be cumulative to and shall not prohibit the enactment of any other general and local laws, rules, and regulations of state or local authorities or agencies and local ordinances prohibiting such activities which are more restrictive than this Code section. 
(d)  Any person who violates this Code section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ga. L. 1897, p. 69, 1; Penal Code 1910, 783; Ga. L. 1916, p. 153, 1; Code 1933, 26-3801, 26-3802; Ga. L. 1957, p. 490, 1-5; Code 1933, 26-1507, enacted by Ga. L. 1976, p. 773, 1; Ga. L. 1978, p. 1658, 1.) 
(i)  For purposes of this section solely, the term utility company shall be defined as: Any company, electrical membership corporation, municipality, or political subdivision engaged in the manufacturer or sale of electricity or provision of natural gas service. 
(Ord. No. 44-10, 9-20-10) 
Sec. 24-12. - Installation of master water meter; requirements. 
Where a master water meter is required under an agreement with Houston County, the city shall provide the required meter, with the party requesting service being responsible for all costs of labor association with the installation. 
(Ord. No. 34-17, § 1, 6-29-17; Ord. No. 42-17, § 1, 8-7-17) 
Secs. 24-14—24-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GAS DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM 

Sec. 24-31. - Emergency powers. 
The mayor, after consultation with appropriate department directors, shall be the authority to invoke provisions of this section when there is an imminent threat to the public well-being and immediate action is deemed necessary in the sole discretion of the mayor to protect the property, health or safety of the citizens of the city. In such event, the mayor shall be authorized to take such action as deemed necessary by him, including, but not limited to, use of water, or termination of natural gas flow, together with authority to order the city police department to enforce any such emergency provisions. 
(Code 1977, § 5-1009) 
Sec. 24-32. - Participation in emergency procedure plan of gas section of Georgia Municipal Association. 
(a)  In the event that the city is called upon to furnish supplies, equipment, machinery and personnel to a neighboring city in distress, the mayor or his designee shall be authorized to furnish the requested equipment, machinery, supplies and personnel in his discretion without further approval of the city. 
(b)  The city agrees to participate in the emergency procedures plan as sponsored by the gas section of the Georgia Municipal Association, and does hereby authorize the mayor or his designee to participate in the plan in behalf of the city. 
(c)  The mayor or his designee is hereby requested to contact the liability insurance carrier of the city and to work out the necessary details to be sure that the liability insurance coverage will be in force on any equipment and machinery which may be furnished under this plan by the city, and he is further requested to take such other action as is necessary to protect any key personnel who may be furnished to a requesting city under the emergency plan. 
(Code 1977, § 5-3005; Res. of 4-6-92) 
Sec. 24-33. - Natural gas system emergency plan adopted. 
The natural gas system emergency plan required by the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968, a copy of which plan is on file with the city clerk, is hereby adopted as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1977, § 5-3006) 
Sec. 24-34. - Maintenance and operation standards adopted. 
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, entitled Approved Standard Maintenance and Operating Procedures for the Natural Gas System in Accordance with Public Law 90-481, is hereby adopted and all the provisions of same are incorporated herein by reference and made a part of this Code as though fully set out at length herein. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1134) 
Sec. 24-35. - Deposit required; tap-on fee; pilot lights. 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  Pilot lights. 
(1)  Except as provided below, a six-dollar fee shall be charged for the initial lighting of a pilot light by city employees. Any lighting of additional pilot lights on the same service call shall require the payment of a two-dollar service fee per lighting. 
(2)  The fees for lighting a pilot light shall not be required when gas service has been interrupted by the city due to emergency or normal gas line maintenance. 
(3)  The fees for lighting pilot(s) shall not be required for new gas account customers. 
(Code 1977, § 5-3001; Ord. No. 55-90, §§ 1, 2, 10-1-90; Ord. No. 55-91, § 8, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 37-10, § 2, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 24-36. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 37-10, § 2, adopted Aug. 16, 2010, deleted § 24-36, which pertained to service charge and derived from Code 1977, § 5-3004. 
Sec. 24-37. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 55-91, § 8, adopted 12-16-91 repealed in its entirety § 24-37, derived from Code 1977, § 5-3007, regarding piping of subdivisions and manufactured home parks for gas service. Said section has been reserved at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 24-38. - Rates, fees and charges generally; meters. 
(a)  Gas rates, fees and charges shall be classified in a reasonable manner to cover users of the services and facilities furnished by the gas system so that these rates, fees and charges shall be as nearly uniform in application to all users falling within any reasonable class as is practicable and no free services shall be furnished at any time from the gas system. All services shall be furnished in accordance with the rates now or hereafter established, including services furnished to any county, municipal corporation or other public body. 
(b)  No gas service shall be furnished except through a meter or other appropriate measuring device. 
(c)  For temporary natural gas service for a period not to exceed a period of three (3) days, a fee of forty-five dollars ($45.00) shall be charged. 
(Code 1977, § 5-3002; Ord. No. 37-10, § 2, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 24-39. - Gas rate schedule. 
(a)  The gas rates shall be as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council and on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  The city's retail natural gas rates as adopted by reference in this section shall be increased or decreased one hundred (100) percent of the incremental increase or decrease in the wholesale rates for natural gas charged by the city's supplier, Southern Natural Gas Company. 
(c)  Inasmuch as the city purchases natural gas on a two-part rate schedule, the incremental increase or decrease shall be the sum of the difference of the old and new demand charges divided by nine and fifteen-hundredths (9.15) plus the difference of the old and new commodity charges. 
(d)  The application of this purchased gas adjustment shall be to the nearest whole cent per MCF (thousand cubic feet). 
(e)  The monthly charge for each gas light shall be the amount fixed from time to time by the mayor and council and on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be increased or decreased as provided in this section. 
(f)  The rate for large industrial customers shall not be subject to the other provisions of this Code section but shall be governed by this subsection: 
(1)  Definitions. The following specific definitions shall apply: 
a.  Large industrial consumer of natural gas means any customer of natural gas to be sold by the city with a consumption in excess of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) worth of natural gas per year. 
b.  Decatherm means one million British thermal units. 
c.  Load factor means the ratio, expressed as a decimal, of the annual peak day's use of natural gas to the annual average day's use of gas. 
d.  Demand charge means the specific rate charged the city as defined in the tariff of the Southern Natural Gas Company. 
e.  Commodity charge means the specific rate charged the city as defined in the tariff of the Southern Natural Gas Company. 
(2)  Rates. The following rates shall be charged in the various classes of industrial service: 
a.  Interruptible (subject to interruption or curtailment in whole or in part for any reason by the city): Currently effective commodity charge of the Southern Natural Gas Company expressed in decatherms multiplied by one hundred ten (110) percent, provided the interruptible consumer shall pay his ratable share (i.e., total charge apportioned between such large industrial consumers according to total use) of the authorized overrun gas (AO gas) as charged to the city by its supplier, Southern Natural Gas Company, in the month of billing. 
b.  Firm rate (not subject to interruption by the city other than for force majeure or curtailment by the pipeline or for other reasons beyond the control of the city): Two dollars and twenty-six cents ($2.26) per decatherm delivered. 
(3)  Changes in rates. At such time as the wholesale rate charged the city by the Southern Natural Gas Company is increased or decreased, the aforestated rates shall be increased or decreased in accordance with the following: 
a.  The interruptible rate shall be as stated above by revised calculation of the newly effective commodity rate of the Southern Natural Gas Company. 
b.  The firm rate shall be calculated at such time as the wholesale rate to the city changes by determining the average cost to the city of the new rate schedule of the Southern Natural Gas Company, utilizing a thirty (30) percent load factor, added to the sum of eighteen cents ($0.18) per decatherm, all converted to cost per decatherm. 
c.  Payment of bills shall be as required by section 24-7 and nonpayment shall subject the user to the interest, penalties and termination of service set out therein. 
(g)  Absent a contractual agreement between the city and an end user, the city's charge for transportation of natural gas will be two dollars ($2.00) per MMBTU. In addition to the transportation fee, the city shall have the right to charge any penalties or fees or additional costs imposed upon the city arising from such transportation of gas. 
(Code 1977, § 5-3003; Ord. No. 53-05, § 2, 11-7-05) 
Sec. 24-40. - Minimum usage for purchase of interruptible gas. 
Only city customers who use an annual minimum of twelve thousand (12,000) MCF per meter will be eligible to purchase natural gas at the interruptible rate. 
(Code 1977, § 5-3008) 
Sec. 24-41. - Financial responsibility of interruptible customers. 
As part of any contractual agreement between the city and a non-governmental industrial end user, the city shall demand adequate assurance of performance. "Adequate assurance of performance" shall mean sufficient security in the form, amount and for the term of any contractual agreements, including, but not limited to, a standby irrevocable letter of credit, a prepayment, a security interest in an asset or a payment bond or guaranty. Said "adequate assurance of performance" shall equal the cost of performing the maximum service requested by the end user for a minimum period of two (2) months at the then-current price of natural gas. Agreements of standby irrevocable letters of credit shall be made with an institution acceptable to the city and shall be renewable on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 53-05, § 1, 11-7-05) 
Secs. 24-42—24-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 25-15, § 1, adopted August 17, 2015, repealed the former article III, §§ 24-56—24-70 and 24-76—24-80, and § 2, of Ord. No. 25-15, enacted a new article III as set out herein. The former article III pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Tables for the article's history. 
Cross reference— Keep Warner Robins Beautiful, § 2-211 et seq.; litter control, § 16-26 et seq. 
State Law reference— Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; Litter Control Law, § 16-7-40 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-56. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and other non-manufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial waste. 
Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable odor-free humus. 
Container means any container which has been approved and provided by either the city or the city's contractor for the use of services provided under this chapter. 
Garbage means the word as commonly used and shall include animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and residue of food and like matter, and other items normally placed in inside household waste containers. 
Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. 
Municipal solid waste means any waste derived from households including garbage, trash, and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from single-family and multi-family residences, hotels, motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day-use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agriculture or silviculture operations, or industrial processes or operations. 
Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including but not limited to municipal solid waste landfills. 
Municipal solid waste landfills means a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludges, or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. 
Trash means items resulting from the normal and necessary activities of residential houses and yards, such as clothing, toys, furniture, magazines, newspapers, cardboard boxes, and other like matter that would be disposed of on an average day. 
Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural, and silvicultural operations. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-57. - City to be exclusive collector; use of service required. 
(a)  Waste collection services shall be provided for exclusively by the city, directly or through contractors; provided however, the city may provide for exceptions by ordinance. 
(b)  All residential properties shall participate in the city's solid waste collection system and pay the designated fees therefor. 
(c)  Commencing March 1, 2018, the city will not provide or regulate solid waste disposal by use of twenty (20), thirty (30), or forty-yard roll-off containers as set forth in code section 24-71. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 3-18-18) 
Sec. 24-58. - Private collection and disposal regulated. 
No person except duly authorized employees of the department of public works or their authorized representatives shall empty garbage, trash, and yard trimmings containers and receptacles, or collect, convey or transfer garbage, trash, yard trimmings, or other refuse through the streets, alleys, or public thoroughfares of the city without a written permit granted and issued by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-59. - Refuse service not available outside the city. 
The city shall not furnish garbage, trash, or yard trimmings collection services outside the city limits, except as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-60. - Owner and operator of premises to maintain container site. 
The owner and/or person in charge of the premises for which a container is permitted, shall, at all times, maintain the premises in a high state of police, free and clear of litter, debris, and trash. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-61. - Approved containers. 
(a)  All customers shall use only those containers issued by the city or the city's contractor pursuant to this article, designed to be rolled to curbside for periodic collection. All containers shall remain the property of the city or the city's contractor. Containers shall be used exclusively for the storage and transport of solid waste to the curbside. 
(b)  If necessary, extra containers may be obtained for an additional monthly fee. 
(c)  If this section is not complied with, the department of public works and the city's contractor may choose to not collect garbage from the customer. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-62. - Refuse not acceptable for collection. 
The following items shall not be collected by the city or the city's contractor: 
(1)  Animal remains, individuals in possession of such should contact 911 emergency services for direction regarding disposal; 
(2)  Ashes of any sort; 
(3)  Automotive parts, including but not limited to the following: car hoods, fenders, grills, tires, axles, motors, transmissions, or car frames; 
(4)  Carpet; 
(5)  Construction or demolition materials, including but not limited to the following: bricks, concrete blocks, wooden boxes, lumber, roofing, sheetrock, or masonite; 
(6)  Dangerous materials or substances, including but not limited to the following: poisons, acids, caustics, infectious materials, explosives, paint, solvents, and petroleum products; 
(7)  Dirt or plant roots containing soil; 
(8)  Discarded hair from barber shops, beauty salons, pet grooming salons, etc., unless such discarded hair is stored in compliance with section 24-66(d); 
(9)  Furniture; 
(10)  Hazardous waste, including but not limited to, material which may be toxic, easily flammable, explosive, reactive, or having toxic characteristics which could threaten public health, property, or the environment; 
(11)  Hypodermic needles, unless such needles are stored in compliance with section 24-66(d); 
(12)  Leaves, limbs, or other trash placed on vacant lots, whether by property owner or violator; 
(13)  Limbs cut and placed near the street for collection by any person other than the resident of the property, unless such individual complies with section 24-73. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-63. - Refuse not acceptable for placement in approved containers. 
(a)  The following items shall be in addition to the items listed in section 24-62 and not be disposed of in approved containers, i.e. dumpsters, roll-off carts, etc., nor will containers be emptied by the department of public works or the city's contractor until such items are removed: 
(1)  Ashes and/or burned material; 
(2)  Bed springs; 
(3)  Household appliances; 
(4)  Liquids, wet garbage, food scraps, etc., of any type that are not in closed or sealed containers; 
(5)  Logs or limbs; 
(6)  Rock, dirt, or concrete blocks; 
(7)  Wooden crates; 
(8)  Yard debris, including grass clippings when mixed with other refuse. 
(b)  For an additional fee, a container will be provided for disposal of any such material listed above that can be placed in the county landfill. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-64. - Medical disability waiver. 
(a)  Households in which all regular residents are mobility-impaired may apply for assisted-collection service. Disability forms, provided by the department of public works, must be completed by each resident and that resident's physician and returned to the department of public works. 
(b)  Upon waiver, the personnel of the city's contractor shall enter upon the customer's property to collect their solid waste from the container on the scheduled day. Such container must be visible to collection personnel from the road and not require personnel to enter a fenced area. Refuse must be placed for collection by 7:30 a.m. only on the residences designated collection day. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-65. - Collection and disposal of garbage. 
(a)  Frequency of service. Garbage shall normally be collected once per-week, with the exception of holiday weeks. The schedule for garbage pickup will be available through the department of public works. Equipment failure or other unforeseeable circumstances may alter the garbage schedule on occasions. 
(b)  Placement. On the customer's designated day for collection, customers shall place their containers at the curbside in front of their residence, specifically on the address side of the street. All containers shall be placed approximately two (2) to four (4) feet from the edge of the roadway. All containers shall not be located in public rights-of-way and shall be located so as to not interfere, block, obstruct, or impede the normal use of any sidewalk, street, alley, driveway, or fire lane, or to block, obstruct, or impede sight distance at street, road, or alley intersections. 
(c)  Container requirements. All garbage must be placed in the customer's container. Garbage shall be physically separated from trash and yard trimmings. All loose debris must be placed in a sealed disposable container. Containers shall not contain the items listed in section 24-62 and 24-63. 
(d)  Compliance required. Unless this section is complied with, the city's contractor and the department of public works may choose to not collect the garbage. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-66. - Collection and disposal of trash. 
(a)  Frequency of service. Trash shall not be collected more than one (1) load at any one (1) location per week. A "load" is defined as one (1) five by ten-foot (5′ × 10′) pile. 
(b)  Placement. On the customer's designated day for collection, customers shall place all trash in a distinct pile between the curb and sidewalk. Where there is no sidewalk, trash may be placed on the property near the street. All trash piles shall be located so as to not interfere, block, obstruct, or impede the normal use of any sidewalk, street, alley, driveway, or fire lane, or to block, obstruct, or impede sight distance at street, road, or alley intersections. City-owned and contractor-owned vehicles shall not enter upon private property to collect trash, and personnel are forbidden to enter upon private property to collect trash which is placed more than five (5) feet behind the street right-of-way. 
(c)  Container requirements. 
(1)  Trash must be placed in a disposable container as the personnel will dispose of the container along with its contents. 
(2)  Trash shall not be placed in the containers. 
(3)  Cardboard boxes shall be collapsed and bundled in a separate pile when not used as a disposable container for other trash. 
(4)  Trash piles shall be separated from yard trimmings piles. 
(5)  Trash piles shall not contain the items listed in sections 24-62 and 24-63. 
(6)  All loose debris must be placed in a sealed disposable container. 
(d)  Compliance required. Unless this section is complied with, the city's contractor and the department of public works may choose to not collect the trash. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-67. - Collection and disposal of yard trimmings. 
(a)  Frequency of service. Yard trimmings shall be collected twice per month with no more than one (1) load at any one (1) location. A "load" is defined as one (1) five by ten-foot (5′ × 10′) pile. 
(b)  Placement. 
(1)  On the customer's designated day for collection, customers shall place all yard trimmings in a distinct pile between the curb and sidewalk. Where there is no sidewalk, yard trimmings may be placed on the property near the street. All yard trimmings piles shall be located so as to not interfere, block, obstruct, or impede the normal use of any sidewalk, street, alley, driveway, or fire lane, or to block, obstruct, or impede sight distance at street, road, or alley intersections. 
(2)  City-owned and contractor-owned vehicles shall not enter upon private property to collect yard trimmings, and personnel are forbidden to enter upon private property to collect yard trimmings which has been placed more than five (5) feet behind the street right-of-way. 
(3)  Yard trimmings shall not be disposed at any municipal solid waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within Warner Robins. 
(4)  The resident of property on which trees over six (6) inches in diameter are cut down, whether by the resident or by another, is required to promptly, within seven (7) days following the cutting, remove or have removed from the property at his own expense, all the limbs, logs, trunks, and tops, or other debris resulting therefrom except for wood retained for firewood. 
(c)  Container requirements. 
(1)  Yard trimmings piles shall be separated from trash piles and garbage. 
(2)  Trash piles shall not contain the items listed in sections 24-62 and 24-63. 
(3)  Limbs and logs up to twelve (12) inches in diameter shall not be over six (6) feet in length. Limbs and logs twelve (12) inches in diameter up to twenty-eight (28) inches in diameter shall not be over two (2) feet in length. 
(4)  All loose debris must be placed in a sealed disposable container. 
(d)  Compliance required. Unless this section is complied with, the city's contractor and the public works department may not collect the yard trimmings. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-68. - Collection and disposal of industrial waste. 
The collection of wastes resulting from manufacturing, assembling, processing, and other industrial operations, waste oils, and other similar materials from garages and filling stations, and accumulations from packing houses, killing and dressing establishments for poultry, and wholesale fruit and vegetable houses shall not be included in the services provided by the department of public works. Such premises or places shall dispose of same at its own expense in the manner and method directed by the county landfill superintendent or Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-69. - Windblown refuse. 
It shall be unlawful to cause, or permit to accumulate, any dust, ashes, trash, or refuse of such material capable of being blown away by the wind anywhere in the city, other than yard trimmings, leaves, and grass, except in a covered container. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-70. - Collection and disposal of medical waste. 
Hospitals and health care professionals or other entities disposing of medical waste including, but not limited to, any device used to puncture or lacerate skin, shall be disposed of in a manner consistent with federal and state regulations. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-71. - Construction site waste. 
(a)  Property owners and/or prime contractors responsible for a construction site shall furnish litter containers for construction and worker litter. All litter from construction activities or any related activities shall be containerized or placed in a twenty (20), thirty (30), or forty-yard roll-off container, and all litter will be placed in containers by workers at the end of each workday. 
(b)  Rocks, waste building materials, and other refuse resulting from construction or remodeling operations or from a general clean-up of property will not be collected by the city. 
(c)  All such litter and waste shall be removed by the building contractor, owner, or occupant of the building at his/her/its expense. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15; Ord. No. 10-18, § 2, 3-18-18) 
Sec. 24-72. - Owner to pay clean-up costs; trapped litter. 
(a)  The owner, occupant, or lessee of all property is required to remove all litter and place the same in a proper container for collection. Vacant lots, borders, parking lots, embankments, fences, walls, and sidewalks are to be kept free of litter. Parking lots, shopping centers, convenience stores, drive-in restaurants, and all commercial and industrial enterprises will ensure that no litter remains on their property. 
(b)  As provided in section 16-31, the city may remove litter from property and assess the cost therefore against the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-73. - Tree service permits; disposal of cutting; fees. 
All holders of tree services licenses or any person engaging in the cutting of trees for a fee paid by the owner or resident of property shall first be required to notify the department of public works giving the location and date of the cutting proposed to be done, as well as the estimated amount of debris which will result. The department of public works will not be responsible for collection of debris except upon request, and payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per load, plus disposal charges where applicable. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-74. - Installation of compactors. 
(a)  The director of public works of the city will review and approve all plans and specifications for the installation of compactor units to be used in connection with containers to this chapter. Such compactors will be approved by the director of public works prior to installation being made. All compactors shredders and compactor containers shall be installed on class A, 3,000-pound-per-square-inch concrete pads of not less than six-inch thickness. All such installations shall comply with the requirements of the building code of the city, the fire prevention code, and other safety laws and ordinances of the mayor and council. The director of public works is further authorized to adopt regulations as may be necessary with reference to such matters. 
(b)  Apartment complexes over one hundred (100) units will be required to utilize compactor units for garbage and trash disposal. 
(c)  Approved compactors will be provided by owner at owner's expense. 
(d)  Compactors will be serviced by the city's authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-75. - Fees for handling refuse, garbage; billing. 
(a)  The following fees shall be charged for the collection and disposal of garbage from any residential property and concern only garbage collection service. These fees will not be waived or adjusted under any circumstances unless authorized by the mayor and council. 
(1)  Each individual residence, per month: Sixteen dollars and fifty cents ($16.50). 
(2)  Residential extra cart: Ten dollars and thirty cents ($10.30). 
(3)  Multiple housing rates, per month: Per manufactured home location: Fifteen dollars and ninety-eight cents ($15.98). 
Per apartment unit: Fifteen dollars and ninety-eight cents ($15.98). 
Manufactured home parks and apartment complexes which are served by a master water meter will be billed at the rate of eighty (80) percent of the total location spaces and/or apartment units available. 
(3)  Compactor charges: 
Monthly rental fee for all compactors provided by the city: 

 
Landfill fee equal to the tipping by one hundred twenty (120) percent for Houston County Landfill (currently twenty-four dollars and sixty cents ($24.60)) per ton) 
(b)  Trash or refuse defined as unacceptable in section 24-62 and section 24-63, except section 24-62 subsections (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (h), and (j) will be collected by the city upon request and upon payment of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per load, plus any applicable disposal charges. 
(c)  The following monthly fees shall be charged for the collection and disposal of garbage from any commercial properties. These fees will not be waived or adjusted under any circumstances unless authorized by mayor and council: 
(1)  Dumpsters. Dumpsters may be used individually or shared with an adjacent business. There will be a maximum of two (2) customers sharing a dumpster and a minimum of two (2) collections weekly for shared dumpsters. For shared dumpsters, the fee for the requested amount of service will be equally divided between the two (2) sharing customers, with the charge for one (1) collection being a minimum charge per customer. Exceptions will be made regarding number sharing only upon approval by director of public works. 
2-yd. Dumpster 

 
4-yd. Dumpster 

 
6-yd. Dumpsters 

 
8-yd. Dumpsters 

 
6-yd. Verti-pak—30-yard 

 
8-yd. Verti-pak—40-yard 

 
Shredder 

 
All dumpsters. verti-paks, and shredder rates shall be based on a rate of $4.20 per cubic yard. 
(2)  Automated collection carts. Customers not requiring dumpsters may choose from the following sizes of automated collection carts. Automated carts may not be shared. The monthly fee for a 90-gallon collection cart with twice per week service shall be $28.30. 
(3)  Compactors. The fee for compactors shall be one hundred ninety seven dollars and seventy-six cents ($197.76) per haul per business establishment plus landfill charges. 
(4)  Customers requesting extra service to dumpsters will be billed at the rate of fifty-four dollars ($54.00) per extra pick up. 
(5)  These fees include only service for refuse containers. Any extra commercially generated trash (or yard trimmings) will be collected upon request and payment of fifty-four dollars ($54.00) per load for acceptable debris or one hundred fifty-four dollars ($154.00) per load, plus landfill charges, for unacceptable debris. 
(d)  The use of containers for the collection and disposal of garbage, trash, construction waste or any other use within the corporate limits of the city shall be accomplished only through the department of public works. The following fees shall be charged for the use of such containers: 

 
(e)  Bills for garbage service shall be rendered along with the bills for utility service as set out in section 24-7 of this Code. 
(f)  If any fee payable under this chapter is not paid by the due date as shown on the bill submitted to customers, a penalty of ten (10) percent of the amount due shall be added and collected. 
(g)  If any fee payable under this chapter shall remain unpaid for fifteen (15) days after the due date, all the customer's utility service shall be terminated until such payment is made. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-76. - Penalty. 
Any person violating, failing, refusing, or neglecting to comply with any provision or requirement of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
DIVISION 2. - AUTOMATED REFUSE CARTS 

Sec. 24-77. - Issuance, responsibility for, maintenance, etc. 
(a)  Initially, an automated refuse cart shall be issued to each occupied residence on each automated route at no charge. The cart is the property of the city's contractor and shall not be removed from the address if the resident should move. A cart identification number will be assigned to the resident's utility account. 
(b)  The cart shall only be removed from the property by duly authorized personnel of the sanitation department or the city's contractor. 
(c)  If the cart is stolen, the resident shall report the theft to the Warner Robins police department and the city's contractor. The automated cart identification number shall be included in any such report. After receipt of the police report, the sanitation department will replace the automated cart at minimal charge to the resident. 
(d)  Upon notification by the resident that repairs to their automated cart are needed, the contractor shall repair the cart so as to place it in good working condition. 
(e)  Ninety-gallon carts will generally be issued to each private residence; however, upon request and availability, 60-gallon carts may be substituted. 
(f)  If one (1) automated cart is not sufficient for the amount of refuse generated weekly, additional cart(s) may be requested from the department of public works. The resident's monthly billing amount will be determined by multiplying the current basic sanitation fee by the number of carts issued to each address. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-78. - Placement for collection; frequency of collection. 
(a)  Automated refuse carts shall be placed immediately adjacent to the street for collection only on designated collection days. 
(b)  Carts shall be placed at the proper location for collection by 7:00 a.m. on designated collection days and shall be removed from the street by 7:00 p.m. of the same day. After one (1) written notice is issued to remove a cart from the street, a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will be imposed for any subsequent violations of this requirement. 
(c)  Carts shall not be placed within four (4) feet of any obstacles, i.e., mailboxes, trash, cars in driveway, etc. 
(d)  Carts shall be placed no more than three (3) feet away from the street for collection. 
(e)  Carts shall be placed with the identification number facing the street. 
(f)  Cars parked on the street must be least fifty (50) feet away from the cart. 
(g)  Carts shall normally be served once weekly. Normal collection days will be Monday through Friday, according to route schedule for address. Equipment failure or other unforeseeable circumstances could alter schedule on occasions. 
(h)  Unless this section is complied with, the city's contractor may not provide service for automated cart. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-79. - Acceptable refuse. 
(a)  The following refuse is acceptable for disposal in automated refuse carts: 
(1)  Household garbage defined as acceptable in section 24-56 of this Code. 
(2)  Trash defined as acceptable in section 24-56 of this Code; provided, however, that trash fits inside the cart without hindering the free flow of refuse from the cart when it is emptied. 
(b)  An automated cart shall not be over-filled so that lid does not close properly. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-80. - Unacceptable refuse. 
(a)  The following items are unacceptable for disposal in automated refuse carts: Any item(s) defined as unacceptable in section 24-62 and section 24-63 of this Code. 
(b)  A fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be imposed on any person found to be guilty of this section in the municipal court. 
(c)  A cart containing unacceptable refuse shall not be emptied until such time the item(s) is (are) removed from the cart. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Sec. 24-81. - Handicapped, disabled customers. 
(a)  Households in which all regular residents are mobility-impaired may apply for assisted-collection service. Disability forms, provided by the department of public works, must be completed by each resident and that resident's physician and returned to the department of public works. 
(b)  If the above requirements are not met, an automated refuse cart will be delivered to the residence and the residence will only receive automated cart collection service. 
(c)  If the above requirements are met, the city's contractor's personnel will provide special service to those residences provided, however, that such residents place their household refuse so as to be visible to collection personnel from the road and so as to not require personnel to enter a fenced area. Additionally, the refuse must be contained in closed, durable plastic bags. Refuse must be placed for collection by 7:30 a.m. only on designated collection days. 
(Ord. No. 25-15, § 2, 8-17-15) 
Secs. 24-82—24-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER SYSTEM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-91. - Reserved.

(a)  No customer shall be connected to the water system of the city, or served thereby, without a proper meter furnished by the utility department having been first installed. The fees for the installation of the water connection shall be charged dependent upon the size of the meter required for the particular connection.

Sec. 24-93. - Water connection fees outside the city. 
(a)  No customer residing outside the city limits shall be connected to the water system of the city, or served thereby, without a proper meter furnished by the utility department of the city having been first installed. The fees for the installation of the water connection shall be charged dependent upon the size of the meter required for the particular connection.

Sec. 24-94. - Rates for water services and facilities; reduced rates, limitations. 
(a)  There shall be a monthly base charge of six dollars and eighty cents ($6.80) per single-family residential water service, plus a volume charge of seventeen and three-tenths cents ($0.173) per one hundred (100) gallons of water used. 
(b)  There shall be a monthly base charge of seventy-five one hundredths (0.75) times the number of living units of multi-family residential dwelling times six dollars and eighty cents ($6.80) plus a volume charge of seventeen and three-tenths cents ($0.173) per one hundred (100) gallons of water used. 
(c)  There shall be a monthly base charge of six dollars and eighty cents ($6.80) per unit of multi-commercial units, plus a volume charge of twenty-five and nine-tenths cents ($0.259) per one hundred (100) gallons of water used. 
(d)  There shall be a monthly base charge of ten dollars and two cents ($10.02) per ERC for commercial and industrial users where the ERC factors by meter size, plus a volume charge of twenty-five and nine-tenths cents ($0.259) per one hundred (100) gallons of water used. 

 
(e)  For temporary water service for a period not to exceed seven (7) days, a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged. For temporary water service for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged. 
(f)  Reserved. 
(g)  Notwithstanding the schedule of rates for use or rental of water services and facilities provided for in this section, the city may from time to time establish lower rates thereof to be charged to churches, hospitals and municipally owned buildings located within the city, provided these lower rates are not to be lower than fifty (50) percent of the rates established herein. 
(Code 1977, §§ 5-2052, 5-2054; Ord. No. 47-89, § 5, 9-18-89; Ord. No. 70-90, § 7, 12-17-90; Ord. No. 55-91, § 7, 12-16-91; Ord. No. 11-93, § 7, 1-5-93; Ord. No. 63-93, § 7, 12-20-93; Ord. No. 56-94, § 7, 12-15-94; Ord. No. 51-96, § 7, 6-27-96; Ord. No. 38-98, § 7, 6-15-98; Ord. No. 55-02, § 1, 6-17-02; Min. of 12-28-05; Ord. No. 24-08, § 2, 6-16-08; Ord. No. 37-10, § 1, 8-16-10; Ord. No. 15-11, § 2, 6-20-11; Ord. No. 14-14, § 1, 6-16-14) 
Sec. 24-95. - Sales to other governmental units. 
The rate for water sold to other governmental units shall be fixed in the resolution of mayor and council authorizing such sales. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2058) 
Sec. 24-96. - Fire hydrant meter policy and procedures. 
A business water service account must be opened at the city's customer service department prior to the issuance of a temporary hydrant meter. 
(1)  Fee schedule: 

 
Note: The account holder will be held responsible for the replacement value (up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)) for tampering with, disassembling, damaging or failing to report the theft of any hydrant meter assembly. 
* Upon closing of the account, usage fees will be deducted from the pre-payment and any remaining credit balance will be returned. 
(2)  Procedures and policies. 
a.  Water business accounts must be opened for a minimum period of sixty (60) days. Following the account set up, a city employee will contact the applicant to arrange for installation of the temporary hydrant meter assembly. The assembly will include a shut-off valve, backflow preventer and security chain. 
b.  Fire hydrant meters will only be issued to the specific requesting party who will utilize the meter and who will be responsible for the meter and payment for water usage. No third party billing will be allowed. 
c.  The hydrant meter assembly will be installed on the nearest fire hydrant to the listed construction site. A representative of the applicant must be on site during the installation to receive operating instructions. 
d.  All customers are responsible for following safe and proper operating procedures. Any damages incurred by the City of Warner Robins to its water distribution system by unsafe or improper operating procedures are the responsibility of the fire hydrant meter customer. 
e.  Hydrant meters should be turned off and on with the attached hand valve only. Verify that vehicle connections are disconnected before moving vehicle. 
f.  Water use fees will be charged against the pre-payment on a monthly basis. Upon retrieval of the hydrant meter assembly and final billing, any remaining credit balance will be returned to the customer. Any credit balances less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will be retained by the city as a processing fee and will not be refunded. 
g.  Monthly charges may include water usage, monthly base fee, late fee, and any damages or penalties incurred by the customer for non-compliance to the policy. Water use charges are based on the city's current water consumption rates for commercial/industrial accounts. 
h.  Hydrant meters are issued for a maximum period of six (6) months for maintenance purposes. A representative with your company must be on site to exchange equipment and complete the necessary forms for the replacement system. 
i.  A replacement hydrant meter assembly will not be issued if the current assembly is damaged, missing, or if the account is delinquent. All accounts must be made current and satisfied before a new fire hydrant meter assembly will be issued. Any additional fire hydrant meters in your possession may be confiscated until all accounts are made current. 
j.  The City of Warner Robins shall have the authority to refuse service to customers who are found to be chronic violators of the fire hydrant meter policy. Violations include disassembly of, excessive damage to, and failure to report a theft in a timely manner of a fire hydrant meter assembly. 
k.  In the event of the theft of issued equipment, a police report must be filed. The customer shall provide the city's utility billing office with a copy of the police report in order to halt monthly billing and avoid forfeiture of the security payment. If a replacement meter is needed, an additional security payment will be required and the account made current prior to issuance of a new system. 
The party to be issued the fire hydrant meter assembly shall be required to sign this statement acknowledging and accepting their responsibilities prior to issuance of the meter assembly. 
Signature _____  Date _______  
Print Name _____   
(Ord. No. 22-13, 8-5-13) 
Secs. 24-97—24-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 24-111. - Definitions. 
The definitions in the Standard Plumbing Code, as adopted and amended by the city, shall apply to the provisions of this division with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes as prescribed below. 
The following definitions apply to the provisions of this division and, where in conflict with any definition of the above cited Standard Plumbing Code, shall be used in lieu of the Southern Standard Plumbing Code definitions with which they are in conflict: 
Airgap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture, or other device and the flood-level rim of the receptacle. 
Approved means accepted by the city as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this division; or as suitable for the proposed use. 
Auxiliary supply means any water source or system other than the potable water supply that may be available in the building or premises. 
Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distributing pipes of a potable supply of water from any source or sources other than its intended source. Backsiphonage is one type of backflow. 
Backflow preventer means a device or means to prevent backflow. 
Backsiphonage means backflow resulting from negative pressures in the distributing pipes of a potable water supply. 
Barometric loop means a loop of pipe rising at least thirty-five (35) feet, at its topmost point, above the highest fixture it supplies. 
Check valve means a self-closing device which is designed to permit the flow of fluids in one (1) direction and to close if there is a reversal of flow. 
Contamination. See "pollution." 
Cross-connection means any physical connection between a potable water supply and any waste pipe, soil pipe, sewer, drain, or any unapproved source or system. Furthermore, it is any potable water supply outlet which is submerged or can be submerged in wastewater and/or any other source of contamination. See "backflow" and "backsiphonage." 
Drain means any pipe that carries wastewater or waterborne wastes in a building drainage system. 
Fixture, plumbing means installed receptacles, devices, or appliances supplied with water or that receive or discharge liquids or liquid-borne wastes. 
Flood-level rim means the edge of the receptacle from which water overflows. 
Hazard, health means any conditions, devices, or practices in the water supply system and its operation which create or, in the judgment of the city, may create, a danger to the health and well-being of the water consumer. An example of a health hazard is a structural defect in the water supply system, whether of location, design or construction, that regularly or occasionally may prevent satisfactory purification of the water supply or cause it to be polluted from extraneous sources. 
Hazard, plumbing means any arrangement of plumbing including piping and fixtures whereby a cross-connection is created. 
Hydropneumatic tank means a pressure vessel in which air pressure acts upon the surface of the water contained within the vessel, pressurizing the water distribution piping connected to the vessel. 
Inlet means the open end of the water supply pipe through which the water is discharged into the plumbing fixture. 
Plumbing system includes the water supply and distribution pipes, plumbing fixtures, and traps; soil, waste, and vent pipes; building drains and building sewers including their respective connections, devices, and appurtenances within the property lines of the premises; and water-treating or water-using equipment. 
Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological, or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water. 
Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer means an assembly of differential valves and check valves including an automatically-opened spillage port to the atmosphere designed to prevent backflow. 
Surge tank means the receiving, nonpressure vessel forming part of the airgap separation between a potable and an auxiliary supply. 
Vacuum means any pressure less than that exerted by the atmosphere. 
Vacuum breaker, nonpressure type means a vacuum breaker designed so as not to be subjected to static line pressure. 
Vacuum breaker, pressure type means a vacuum breaker designed to operate under conditions of static line pressure. 
Water, nonpotable means water that is not safe for human consumption or that is of questionable potability. 
Water, potable means water free from impurities in amounts sufficient to cause disease or harmful physiological effects. Its bacteriological and chemical quality shall conform to the requirements of the federal drinking water standards or to the regulations of the state environmental protection division and county health department. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059) 
Cross reference— Plumbing code adopted, § 6-211. 
Sec. 24-112. - Backflow prevention device. 
(a)  All existing plumbing in every building or premises inside the city and/or connected to the city water system which has the possibility of contamination or pollution of the city water system shall have installed within twelve (12) months of December 16, 1985 suitable backflow prevention devices approved by the city. 
(b)  All new plumbing in every building or premises inside the city and/or to be connected to the city water system which has the possibility of contamination or pollution of the city water system shall have installed prior to the connection of the plumbing to the city water system suitable backflow prevention devices approved by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(b)(1), (2)) 
Sec. 24-113. - Emergency supply; inspection; right of entry. 
(a)  The city shall identify and provide for emergency sources of water supply to the city water system during and in the event of contamination or pollution of the city water system by a customer. 
(b)  The city, its director of municipal utilities, or his designated agents shall inspect the plumbing in every building or premises inside the city and/or connected or to be connected to the city water supply as frequently as in his judgment may be necessary to ensure that such plumbing has been installed, or will be installed, in such a manner as to prevent the possibility of contamination or pollution of the water supply of the city by the plumbing. The inspector shall notify or cause to be notified in writing the owner or authorized agent of the owner of any such buildings or premises to correct, within a reasonable time set by the city, any plumbing installed or existing contrary to or in violation of this section and which, in his judgment, may therefore permit the contamination or pollution of the city water system or otherwise adversely affect the public health. 
(c)  The city, its director of municipal utilities, or his designated agents shall have the right of entry into any building or premises inside the city and/or connected or to be connected to the city water system during reasonable hours for the purpose of making inspection of the plumbing systems installed in such building or premises; provided that, with respect to the inspection of any single-family dwelling, consent to such inspection shall first be obtained from a person of suitable age and discretion therein or in control thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(b)(3)—(5)) 
Sec. 24-114. - Purpose and policy. 
The city has a responsibility to provide its customers at the service connection with water that is safe under foreseeable circumstances. In the exercise of this responsibility, the city must take reasonable precaution to protect the city water system from the hazards originating on the premises of its customers that may degrade the water in the city water system. The city should take such measures as it may deem necessary to ensure that the city water system is protected from contamination. Such action should include provision for the installation of a backflow prevention device, consistent with the degree of hazard, at the service connection, or discontinuance of the service. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(a)(1)) 
Sec. 24-115. - Objectives. 
The objectives of this division are to: 
(1)  Protect the public water supply against contamination or pollution resulting from backflow of objectionable matter through cross connections; 
(2)  Protect the public water supply against a hazard or potential hazard found, originating or potentially originating on a customer's premises; 
(3)  Establish a cross connection control and backflow prevention program for the city water system; 
(4)  Provide technical provisions for eliminating backflow and cross connections; 
(5)  Provide penalties for violation of the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(a)(2)) 
Sec. 24-116. - Violations. 
(a)  The city shall notify the owner or authorized agent of the owner of the building or premises in which there is found a violation of this division, of such violation. The city shall set a reasonable time for the owner to have the violation removed or corrected. Upon failure of the owner to have the defect corrected by the end of the specified time interval the city may, if in its judgment an imminent health hazard exists, cause the water service to the buildings or premises to be terminated, and/or recommend such additional fines or penalties to be invoked as herein may be provided. 
(b)  The owner or authorized agent of the owner responsible for the maintenance of the plumbing systems in the building who knowingly permits a violation to remain uncorrected after the expiration of time set by the city shall be guilty of an offense. 
(c)  The city's marshal is authorized to issue a citation for any violation of this division. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(e); Ord. No. 58-90, § 1, 10-1-90) 
Sec. 24-117. - Program adopted. 
The Cross-Connection Control and Backflow Prevention Program Manual prepared by Flood Engineers, dated July, 1985 is adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 76-85, 12-16-85) 
Sec. 24-118. - Installation and maintenance. 
A potable water supply system shall be designed, installed and maintained in such manner as to prevent contamination from nonpotable liquids, solids or gases from being introduced into the potable water supply through cross-connections or any other piping connections to the system. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(1)) 
Sec. 24-119. - Cross-connections prohibited. 
Cross-connections between potable water systems and other systems or equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable safety are prohibited except when and where, as approved by the city, suitable protective devices such as the reduced pressure zone backflow preventer or equal are installed, tested and maintained to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(2)) 
Sec. 24-120. - Interconnections. 
Interconnection between two (2) or more public water supplies shall be permitted only with the approval of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(3)) 
Sec. 24-121. - Individual water supplies. 
Cross-connections between an individual water supply and a potable public supply shall not be made unless specifically approved by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(4)) 
Sec. 24-122. - Connections to boilers. 
Potable water connections to boilers shall be made through an airgap or provided with an approved backflow preventer. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(5)) 
Sec. 24-123. - Prohibited connections to fixtures and equipment. 
Connection to the potable water supply system for the following is prohibited unless protected against backflow as set out herein: 
(1)  Bidets. 
(2)  Operating, dissection, embalming, and mortuary tables or similar equipment; in such installation, the hose used for water supply shall terminate at least twelve (12) inches away from every point of the table or attachments. 
(3)  Pumps for nonpotable water, chemicals or other substances, priming connections may be made only through an airgap. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(6)) 
Sec. 24-124. - Refrigerating unit condensers and cooling jackets. 
Except where potable water provided for a refrigerator condenser or cooling jacket is entirely outside the piping or tank containing a toxic refrigerant, the inlet connection shall be provided with an approved check valve. Also adjacent to and at the outlet side of the check valve, an approved pressure relief valve set to relieve at 5 psi above the maximum water pressure at the point of installation shall be provided if the refrigeration units contain more than twenty (20) pounds of refrigerants. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(7)) 
Sec. 24-125. - Degree of hazards. 
Cross-connections, direct or indirect, are classified as presenting one (1) of the following degrees of hazard to the city water system: 
(1)  Severe means a condition that could subject the city water system to any liquid, solid or gaseous foreign substance, including raw sewage and lethal substances, that when introduced into the water supply creates or would create death, a danger to the health, or a danger to the well-being of the consumer. Protection as a minimum shall be by the installation of a reduced pressure principal backflow preventer located at the water service connection on the downstream side of the water meter, plus any other protection as deemed necessary by the city. 
(2)  Moderate means a condition that could subject the city water system to any liquid, solid or gaseous foreign substances, including food, beverages, nontoxic and nonpoisonous substances, that when introduced into the water supply creates or would create in sufficient concentrations a nuisance or aesthetically objectionable water supply to the customer. Protection as a minimum shall be by the installation of a double check valve assembly backflow preventer located at the water service connection on the downstream side of the water meter or/plus any other protection as deemed necessary to by the city. 
(3)  Minor means a condition that could subject the public water supply to any liquid, solid or gaseous foreign substance, including such substances as rust, sulphur, carbon dioxide, etc., that when introduced into the water supply in large concentrations creates or would create only a very temporary, very localized, aesthetically objectionable water supply to the customer. Protection shall be by the installation of appropriate backflow prevention devices on a per case basis. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(8)) 
Sec. 24-126. - Protection against backflow and backsiphonage. 
(a)  Water outlets. A potable water system shall be protected against backflow and backsiphonage by providing and maintaining at each outlet: 
(1)  Airgap. An airgap, as specified in subsection (b)(2), between the potable water outlet and the flood-level rim of the fixture it supplies, or between the outlet and any other source of contamination; or 
(2)  Backflow preventer. A device or means to prevent backflow. 
(b)  Minimum required airgap. 
(1)  How measured. The minimum required airgap shall be measured vertically from the lowest end of a potable water outlet to the flood rim or line of the fixture or receptacle into which it discharges. 
(2)  Size. The minimum required airgap shall be twice the effective opening of a potable water outlet unless the outlet is a distance less than three (3) times the effective opening away from a wall or similar vertical surface, in which cases the minimum required airgap shall be three (3) times the effective opening of the outlet. In no case shall the minimum required airgap be less than shown in the Standard Plumbing Code. 
(c)  Approval of devices. Before any device for the prevention of backflow or backsiphonage is installed, it shall have first been certified by a recognized testing laboratory acceptable to the city. Devices installed in a building potable water supply distribution system for protection against backflow shall be maintained in good working condition by the person responsible for the maintenance of the system. The city shall inspect routinely such devices and if found to be defective or inoperative shall require the replacement thereof. 
(d)  Installation of devices. 
(1)  Vacuum breakers. Vacuum breakers shall be installed with the critical level at least six (6) inches above the flood-level rim of the fixture they serve and on the discharge side of the last control valve to the fixture. No shutoff valve or faucet shall be installed beyond the vacuum breaker. For closed equipment or vessels such as pressure sterilizers the top of the vessel shall be treated as the flood-level rim but a check valve shall be installed on the discharge side of the vacuum breaker. 
(2)  Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. A reduced pressure principle type backflow preventer may be installed subject to full static pressure. 
(3)  Devices of all types. Backflow and backsiphonage preventing devices shall be accessibly located preferably in the same room with the fixture they serve. Installation in utility or service spaces, provided they are readily accessible, is permitted. Vacuum breakers and backflow preventers equipped with atmosphere vents or with relief openings shall be so installed and so located as to prevent any vent or any relief opening from being submerged. The preventing devices shall be installed in the position as required by the manufacturer and shall be protected from freezing. 
(4)  Thermal expansion control. Where water is heated in a distribution system or a branch of the system that has been provided a vacuum breaker or backflow preventer, a thermal expansion control device shall be installed between the vacuum breaker or backflow preventer and the water heater to limit the static pressure increase due to thermal expansion of the heated water. 
(e)  Tanks and vats: below rim supply. 
(1)  Where a potable water outlet terminates below the rim of a tank or vat and the tank or vat has an overflow of diameter not less than given in the Standard Plumbing Code, the overflow pipe shall be provided with an airgap as close to the tank as possible. 
(2)  The potable water outlet to the tank or vat shall terminate a distance not less than one and one-half (1½) times the height to which water can rise in the tank above the top of the overflow. This level shall be established at the maximum flow rate of the supply to the tank or vat and with all outlets except the airgap overflow outlet closed. 
(3)  The distance from the outlet to the high water level shall be measured from the critical point of the potable water supply outlet. 
(f)  Connections not subject to backpressure. Where a water connection is not subject to backpressure, a vacuum breaker shall be installed on the discharge side of the last valve on the line serving the fixture or equipment. 
(g)  Connections subject to backpressure. Where a potable water connection is made to a line, fixture, tank, vat, pump or other equipment with a hazard of backflow or backsiphonage where the water connection is subject to backpressure, and an airgap cannot be installed, the city shall classify the connection as to the degree of hazard and shall require the installation of backflow preventers required by the degree of hazard as set forth in subsection (d)(3) of this section. Such connections include, but are not limited to, chemical lines, individual water supplies, industrial process water lines, pressure tanks, pumps, steam lines, swimming pools, tanks and vats (bottom inlets), and hose bibbs. 
(h)  Barometric loop. Water connections where an actual or potential backsiphonage hazard exists may in lieu of devices specified above be provided with a barometric loop. Barometric loops shall precede the point of connection. 
(i)  Low pressure cutoff required on booster pumps. When a booster pump is used on a water pressure booster system and the possibility exists that a positive pressure of 10 psi or less may occur on the suction side of the pump, there shall be installed a low-pressure cutoff on the booster pump to prevent the creation of a vacuum or negative pressure on the suction side of the pump, thus cutting off water to other outlets. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(9)) 
Sec. 24-127. - Maintenance requirements. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be the responsibility of building and premises owners to maintain all backflow preventers and vacuum breakers within the building or on the premises in good working order and to make no piping or other arrangements for the purpose of bypassing backflow devices. 
(b)  Backflow preventer. Periodic testing and inspection schedules shall be established by the city for all backflow preventers and the interval between such testing and inspections and overhauls of each such device shall be established in accordance with the age and condition of the device. Inspection intervals should not exceed one (1) year, and overhaul intervals should not exceed five (5) years. These devices should be inspected frequently after the initial installation to assure that they have been installed properly and that debris resulting from the installation has not interfered with the functioning of the device. The testing procedures shall be in accordance with the device manufacturer's instructions. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2059(d)(10)) 
Secs. 24-128—24-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WATER CONSERVATION MEASURES 

Sec. 24-146. - Compliance with division required. 
No person shall knowingly cause, use, or permit the use of water from the city system for any purpose in any manner contrary to any provision of this division or in an amount in excess of that use permitted by the conservation stage in effect pursuant to action taken by the mayor, or designee, in accordance with the provisions of this division. As used in this division, "person" shall include individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, and all other legal entities. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2060) 
Sec. 24-147. - Mayor shall promulgate guidelines. 
The mayor shall promulgate guidelines which set forth the criteria for determining when a particular conservation state is to be implemented and terminated. Such guidelines shall be published and available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk. These guidelines shall be updated when, in the discretion of the mayor, the conditions of the water system have changed so as to necessitate such an update. These guidelines shall be based upon present consumption, rate of replenishment into the water system, weather conditions, and consideration of public health, safety, welfare, and livelihood. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2061) 
Sec. 24-148. - Implementing water conservation conditions. 
Based upon established guidelines promulgated pursuant to this division, the mayor shall designate the appropriate conservation conditions that the users of the city water system shall follow. These conditions are: 
(1)  Condition I. Water shortage possibility. Water used for irrigation of vegetation may be used on such day or days of the week, on premises the street number of which is an odd number and on even numbered premises on alternative days, as the mayor shall so designate. Premises having no number shall apply to the city building official for an alternate day assignment. Such days may be changed for any customer in the discretion of the mayor. No customer shall permit water to run or waste in any gutter or otherwise. 
(2)  Condition II. Water shortage watch. 
a.  All provisions of condition I shall remain in effect as well as those of condition II. The sprinkling or watering of lawns is prohibited. However, the mayor may authorize the watering of trees, shrubbery, plants, gardens and flowers through the means of a hand held hose equipped with a positive shut off nozzle, drip irrigation or a hand held bucket or water can. When authorized, such watering shall be done only during the hours and days as directed by the mayor. Commercial nurseries shall be exempt from this prohibition and permitted to use sprinkler irrigation systems between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. to maintain nursery stock provided irrigation water is recaptured and recirculated. Residential homeowners and occupants may install and water on day of purchase of such nursery stock, excluding lawns. 
b.  The washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers, boats, airplanes, and any other type of mobile equipment is prohibited except that individuals may wash their private cars or boats if they use a bucket, pail, or normal sized receptacles; and further provided, that filling stations shall wash their customer's cars with a bucket, pan, pail or other receptacles not larger than that of five-gallon capacity; however, an individual or filling station, after such washing, shall be permitted to rinse the car or boat off with a hose, using only a reasonable amount of water in so doing. Commercial or automatic car wash establishments shall use minimum practical water settings. 
c.  The washing of exteriors and interiors of buildings, trailers, and manufactured homes except that in the interest of public health is prohibited. The director of public health may permit limited use of water as the case may be. 
d.  The permitting or maintaining of defective plumbing in a home, business establishment or any location where water is used on the premises is prohibited. The wasting of any water by reason of defective plumbing as hereinabove mentioned shall include the existence of out-of-repair water closets, underground leaks, defective faucets and taps. The permitting of water to flow constantly through a tap, hydrant, valve or otherwise by any user of water connected to the city system shall be considered as a wasting of water and prohibited. 
e.  The use of fire hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting is prohibited without permission of the fire chief. 
f.  The use of water in ornamental foundations or in artificial water falls where the water is not reused or recirculated in any manner is prohibited. 
g.  The use of water to wash down any sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts or other hardsurfaced area, or building or structure is prohibited. 
h.  The use of water for dust control is prohibited. 
i.  The use of potable water by a golf course to irrigate any portion of its ground except those areas designated as tees and greens and only between designated hours on the designated watering days, as determined by the mayor, is prohibited. 
j.  Any use of water for the purposes or in a manner prohibited in this section shall be deemed to be a waste of water and any person violating any of the provisions of this condition and any person in which name a water meter connection is registered in the utility department, which water connection serves premises upon which a violation occurs, and proof that the particular premises have a water meter connection registered in the name of the defendant named in the complaint, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the person in whom such water connection was registered was the person who permitted or caused the act of waste charged to occur on the premises. 
k.  Concurrently with the implementation of condition II, the mayor shall appoint an allocation and review committee, as hereinafter provided, for the purpose of reviewing water conservation policies and establishing exemptions. 
(3)  Condition III. Water shortage warning. Upon implementation by the mayor and publication of notice, the following restrictions shall apply to all persons. The mayor, in the exercise of his discretion based upon the guidelines, may implement any or all of those elements of condition III as are deemed necessary at any particular time. All elements of condition II shall remain in effect in condition III. 
a.  New service connections to the city's water system are prohibited where some other source independent of the city's water system is existing and in use on January 5, 1987. 
b.  The mayor may establish a mandatory limit of normal water use by customers without use penalty. 
c.  In connection with the enforcement of subsection (3)b, the mayor shall establish a maximum limit beyond which water service will be terminated. 
d.  The use of water to serve a customer in a restaurant unless requested by the customer is prohibited. 
e.  The use of water for the expansion of commercial nursery facilities is prohibited. 
f.  The use of water for scenic and recreational ponds and lakes is prohibited. 
g.  The use of water for private, single-family residential swimming pools, wading pools, jacuzzi pools, hot tubs and like or similar use is prohibited. 
h.  The use of water for municipally-owned swimming pools is prohibited. 
i.  The use of water for privately-owned neighborhood and subdivision swimming pools accessible to the public and swimming pools owned by country clubs, athletic clubs, health clubs, fraternal organizations and other like or similar pools is prohibited. 
j.  The use of water for hotel, motel, condominium, apartment and other multi-family, residential-user swimming pools, including commercial and business swimming pools is prohibited. 
k.  The use of water to put new agricultural land into production is prohibited. 
l.  The use of water for new planting or landscaping is prohibited. 
m.  When watering of plants is authorized by the mayor, such watering shall be permitted only during the designated hours and designated watering days. 
(4)  Condition IV. Water shortage emergency. Upon implementation by the mayor and publication of notice, the following restrictions shall apply to all persons. The mayor, in the exercise of his discretion based upon the guidelines, may implement any or all of those elements of condition IV as are deemed necessary at any particular time. All elements of condition III shall remain in effect in condition IV. 
a.  No applications for new, additional, further expanded, or increased-in-size water service connections, meters, service lines, pipeline extensions, mains, or other water service facilities of any kind shall be allowed, approved, or installed except as approved by the allocation and review committee. 
b.  All allocations of water use to industrial and commercial customers shall be in amounts as established after consultation with the allocation and review committee. 
c.  The maximum monthly use for a residential customer shall be established with revised rate schedules and penalties by the mayor in the recommendation by the allocation and review committee. 
d.  The mayor shall take those actions deemed necessary to meet the conditions resulting from the emergency. 
(Code 1977, § 5-2062) 
Sec. 24-149. - Allocation and review committee; establishment, composition, powers and duties. 
(a)  The allocation and review committee shall be composed of the mayor, three (3) councilmembers, the director of utilities, the director of county health unit, a representative of industry, a representative of business and commerce and a citizen of the city. The industry, business and citizen members shall be appointed by the mayor.
